text: I need help I clean a clients shower today and was I was doing my final walkthrough I noticed some small scratches. I didnâ€™t notice these before but this is my first time cleaning for her. Idk if I made them or not but Iâ€™m sick to my stomach. How can I fix these? They are not deep at all just tiny. I used 0000 steel wool when cleaning the doors.

topComments.text: first off dont use steel wool.. only when really really thick with limescale .. 2nd ... if you are not sure if you've made the scratches then do not mention ... I know this might sound a bit underhand if maybe u have scratched it but if you're not sure then just leave it. if client them mentions it explain you did notice it but did not mention it astounding were unsure if not already there and 3rd ... have an eye for detail before u start your clean.. ive been here several times before and marks have already been there .. also dont worry ... u will come across all sorts of things / marks that can make you question yourself. in the end uou become used to it. I only ever speak to client if we are 100 per cent we made an error
I do not use steel wool. Ever.

text:
Hey everyone, Iâ€™m currently looking for cleaners to employ on a part time/full time basis. Iâ€™ve tried several hiring platforms including indeed, next door, zip recruiter, barefoot students, Craigslist. I do get some applicants but itâ€™s either they donâ€™t show up for interview, they show up but donâ€™t seem like who we can work with, language barrier, or they just drop somewhere in the onboarding process. What do you suggest is the reason? Am I not looking enough? 
The pay rate is decent for the location so I donâ€™t believe itâ€™s the compensation. Moreover, thereâ€™s a lot of benefits with my company.
Anyone know a good place to find cleaners and what strategies did you implement in your hiring process?

topComments.text: We switched to group interviews and that really helped broaden the amount of applicants we could screen. If they showed up, followed instructions and sent over 3 references, they passed the first screening. Then we moved into interviewing the best possible applicants with phone interviews, zoom interviews and a working interview. If they passed there, we can hire and start training. It's a process. Definitely takes several weeks to find someone suitable.

I use my local community pages on FB most cityâ€™s have a FB page for that location ie christchurch jobs or Christchurch gig work pages and Iâ€™ve had some good and not so good applicants, screening process is really important, I ask them to email their CV then I do a telephone interview if there are no reg flags I do an in person interview and then get them to do a trail day with me, you can quickly see on that trail day if they are going to be of any benefit or not, good luck

text: Question... I recently transitioned my ICs to W2 employees. We are now implementing 30min lunch breaks and everyone seems to be struggling with this. I need some help. Should they clock out once they finish the first home and that starts the 30min break, or drive to where they are eating and then clock out? I hadn't put much thought into it, but with there being so much confusion I want black and white steps for reference. Thank you in advance!

topComments.text: I actually give my cleaners the choice to take a 30 minute unpaid break or to get a paid lunch by eating while driving to the next client.  If they choose to take unpaid 30 mins - they clock out when they are done cleaning and then drive to wherever they are eating lunch.  Then clock back in for travel to the next client.  I also still give them mileage reimbursement from client to client, even if they clocked out for lunch.
Hey Ashley, try copying & pasting this into chat gpt, it just gave me exactly what you were looking for!

text: Today I had a cleaning tech clean her first house alone. Sheâ€™s been killing it and to be honest had high expectations.I did a quality check without her, expecting it, and was deeply disappointed by what I found. She didnâ€™t clean the floor around the toilet. She didnâ€™t empty the bathroom, trash there were places where she clearly didnâ€™t dust anything at all. Iâ€™m stumped. How did she go from stellar performance to complete bullshit? She even sent me a text message saying that she killed it. I accept full responsibility for this. I know this means I have not done a good job training but what else do I need to know about the scenario?

topComments.text: In our experience, this is part of the arc of leaning. Phase one of training includes constant supervision. Phase 2, we show up at the end of every clean and give feedback and even assist in getting the house to standard. Phase 3 we release them from training and give them a raise. In phase 3, we can observe the battle between Accomplishing our standard and accomplishing the budgeted amount of time. in this phase. We are often giving clients partial refunds, and sometimes we even lose a client or two. But, eventually, the right hire will begin to accomplish our standard in the time we have set for them, and they themselves become an excellent technician. ï¿¼

I'm not sure what went wrong here but what I will say is that "top to bottom left to right" doesn't make sense to every brain so if that is your only method to training then I would revisit bathrooms and Kitchen and give a step by step process vs that typical advice. Top to bottom left to right is not obvious in those areas, it's not a fool-proof method.

text:
Iâ€™m working on strengthening company culture and support for my cleaners. 
What specific things have helped you build a positive, uplifting environment for your teams? Any routines, incentives, communication styles, or leadership habits that have made a noticeable impact?

topComments.text:
My leadership team and I celebrate every win no matter how small.  We use a group chat app that allows multiple chat threads and we have a Kudos one.  We put shout outs, positive feedback, kudos alerts, etc on there.  

I was very intentional
about how I wanted to lead my team as I grew my business - we believe in servant leadership which is basically â€œIâ€™m here to support you, my team member and you are here to support the client â€œ.  It takes a lot of effort to keep things positive - you have to be intentional about it every day.  But it has made our team strong and kept my turnover very low.

Celebrate every win in business with the team that brought that to you. Every new client, every tip given, every compliment given is a result of your hard and theirs so celebrate that as much as you can. We have meetings every other week. We have Thanksgiving bundles(turkey, gravy,cranberry sauce and sparkling grape juice) to each team member. Weâ€™re having our Christmas party next week and giving bonuses and company swag to them

text: Hi everyone, this is a bit of a delicate subject, but Iâ€™m not sure how to approach it.  I would much rather try and fix this, but Iâ€™m not sure how to handle it at this point. I have an employee who gives off a very strong body odour while cleaning. I found that she will come to work without a smell, but as soon as she starts moving, the odour is intense. I have had a talk with her already about it, but I need to talk to her about it again because itâ€™s becoming an issue. Clients are noticing it and it lingers. What do I do?

topComments.text: Something on the inside is happening if someone is smelling that strongly and regularly showering. I would send out a group message to all employees reminding them about practicing proper hygiene and if it doesnâ€™t change then I would have to have a discussion with her and bring it to her attention that clients are noticing. For women especially, it can be a hormonal issue as well. Be gentle and kind, itâ€™s uncomfortable for all involved.

text:
What do you all do with a team member who is part time who calls in frequently? 

She has been with us almost 2 months and has called off 4xâ€™s. Am I crazy or is that a pattern? 

Her reasons are all different but I have 2 other team members who have been with us for 6+months and have yet to call in. 

She seems genuinely apologetic and she works another part time job but I want to set healthy boundaries as to not display bad leadership. 

What policies do you set in place for part time team members?

topComments.text: Hello everyone , but how you dealt with independent contractors cleaners, like I have one call just 1 hour before  and said canâ€™t   go to the job site.

I actually just went through this exact situation last Tuesday and had to terminate an employee for the same reason. Our employee handbook outlines everything very clearly â€” the training/probation period is 90 days, and a detailed review happens at 60 days. Employees cannot have more than two unexcused call-offs within any six-month period. That policy is intentionally in place to filter out unreliable hires early. Frequent call-offs in the first six months always become bigger problems later.

This employee had already received a written warning on 10/28 when she reached 1 point. When I ran a full report last Monday, she actually had 4.5 points â€” the admin had not been calculating her late arrivals correctly. That same day, she emailedâ€”after being on the clock for over an hourâ€”saying she was leaving. She had cleaned one small break room at a commercial site and walked out. I terminated her the next day. She was fully aware that attendance was already an issue.

Sympathy aside, our business only operates when the work is taken seriously. My commercial accounts expect their spaces to be cleaned when they walk in, and at midnight thereâ€™s no one available to cover a last-minute call-off. The timing was unfortunate because weâ€™re entering our busiest season with holidays and Michigan winter weather, but she was simply too unpredictable. She ended up being terminated exactly at her 60-day mark.

My other two employees are fully scheduled, so Iâ€™m the buffer right now â€” which is challenging because I also handle daytime operations. Finding employees with solid attendance has been one of the biggest hurdles, and honestly Iâ€™m likely pausing hiring until the new year to avoid onboarding someone during Christmas break.

My honest advice:
Revisit your employee handbook and make sure your attendance policies are clearly outlined, signed, and consistently enforced. If you donâ€™t follow your own policies, employees will walk all over you â€” not maliciously, but because youâ€™ve shown them there are no real consequences. They are not your friends; they are your employees, and the tone you set early determines how seriously they take the role. Even someone whoâ€™s been with you five years will push boundaries if expectations arenâ€™t upheld from the beginning.

text: I completed the biggest job of my business so far on November 29. It was a move out clean house being put on the market. They paid promptly after the house was photographed by the realtors on December 2 and I have received the payment. I havenâ€™t received any feedback and Iâ€™m wondering how do I go about professionally seeking feedback from somebody who used my company to help them sell their home? I guess I could ask ChatGPT but Iâ€™m asking yâ€™all.

topComments.text: Our pipeline goes: new lead > walk-through > proposal > no-answer > approved > on schedule > complete > payment received. Most pipeline phases include automations. When it moves to 'payment received,' the automation sends a text message thanking and asking for a review. A couple of days later, if the review is not received, we send an email asking. If not received, we send another text message, then another two emails. People are busy and can not do it right away, so the reminders help a lot.

Unless I misunderstanding (very possible) why not just call them and ask? 

Hey Mrs. Jones, this is xxxx owner of xxxx. We cleaned your house last week to prep it for pictures.  Did everything look good? Happy to send the team over for any touch ups if needed! 

Etc. If I do this I normally add the question- when is the house going to be listed? I am happy to share the listing on my social media!

text:
Have you ever had to â€œfireâ€ a client? 

I had to a few months ago, and my only thoughts on the matter are that I wish I would have done it sooner. My employee still tells me how thankful she is that I dropped the client, because she made her so uncomfortable every time! Good riddance.

I would just love some anecdotes so, forbid this happens again, I can handle it better. Confrontation is one of my weakest points.

topComments.text: Absolutely. I dropped a client because he told me he wouldnâ€™t be home, but when I tried contacting him to confirm a new clean time because we were running late, he was out of service range. Thatâ€™s fine, in those cases we just reschedule because Iâ€™m not about to get caught in someoneâ€™s house at the wrong time. He called me back halfway through when we were supposed to be there and screamed at me. I specifically remember him saying that if I have policies in place for when clients cancel last minute, I better have a policy in place for when WE cancel last minute. This was after I explained to him the policy about not being able to get ahold of him in the first place. I just told him we werenâ€™t a good fit anymore and cancelled his service. He gave me some flack but in the end he said â€œgood luck in businessâ€ and that was it

I fire clients all the time. As I get more serious about who I am as a business owner and what I want to do and achieve I see this as a natural process. I am not emotional about it. Stepping stones - they are all stepping stones.

text: I am looking for good training ideas for my weekly team meetings (3 cleaners). Meetings last 30-60min.

attachments.alt: May be an image of text that says 'Workshop Development 1 Learna Å›kills TRAINING Coaching à¹“ Teaching Knowledge'

topComments.text: I am very alarmed at the number of business owners that recommend to meet with cleaners only once a month or every other month. I was an owner/operator for 8 out of the 12 years that Iâ€™ve been in business. This business can be very lonely for our cleaners that work independently on a daily basis. Some are more introverted and donâ€™t mind the non social aspect of the job. Itâ€™s my firm belief that the reason our industry experiences such high turnover rates is because our cleaners are not engaged with the team or feeling appreciated. The sole purpose of having weekly meetings with my team is to bring everyone together, bring them breakfast and just talk to them like they are human and not work horses for our company. Can a business still be profitable paying for an hour of our cleaners time to sit and learn and get to know one another on a better level, absolutely. Thank you for those that offered your ideas on what to train on. And no, we donâ€™t just train every week. Sometimes we just come together and share a meal together that I provide.

text:
So today I had a difficult situation for a cleaner. They were doing a clean for a 50 year old male that said they were disabled. They arrived and got to work. However, then things started to get weird. The client said some strange things:
1) he said he was going to leave a $500 tip,
2) he said he was very lonely,
3) he said his previous cleaner used to sleep with him
4) he then walked to the toilet in his boxer shorts (so not disabled)
3) he asked the cleaner when last she had kissed someone, she said she had a fiance, to which he replied, 'that is not what I asked'. 

At this point the cleaner said she had an emergency and left the property. 

She called me up hyperventilating and explained what had happened and that she felt very vulnerable. We calmed her down, did a full debrief and asked if she wanted to report the incident to the authorities - she did not want to. We have written to the client advising we are terminating services due to 'conduct during the service which made it unable to safely continue'. We're also creating a policy to ensure this never happens again. Unfortunately though there is no way to 100% screen against this.

I am asking for any input on what you do to protect staff. Our cleaners work solo but I'm considering either insisting on having crews work in pairs where a solo male client is home. text:
How are we handling dishes? We charge flat and pay flat rate so itâ€™s a variable that is throwing kinks into our flow. When I was solo, I always happily did the dishes whether loaded in dishwasher or hand washed, no questions asked. 98% of clients donâ€™t leave any or many dishes and a few have a sink full(usually busy families, and I GET IT!). But Iâ€™ve had many cleaners get very disgruntled over being asked to do dishes, so we changed the policy to this: 

1. Check the dishwasher: If thereâ€™s room and dishes are clearly dirty, load what you can.

If itâ€™s full of clean dishes, do not unload â€” just skip.

2. Use your judgment: If itâ€™s just a few dishes(10 or less) do a quick hand wash and leave them to dry on a towel or rack.

If itâ€™s a full sink or the dishes are old or grimy, skip it â€” we donâ€™t expect you to scrub heavy buildup or pots and pans.

3. Clean the sink area regardless: Move dishes aside, clean the sink, faucet, and counters, then replace them neatly.

4. Snap a photo and leave a note in ZenMaid

Example:
â€œSink was full of dishes. I wiped around the area but skipped washing. See attached photo.â€

This is not working because â€œuse your judgementâ€ = inconsistency and some cleaners are skipping this 2 minute task. So Iâ€™m wanting to hear some other â€œdish policiesâ€ to see if Iâ€™m asking too much of them.

topComments.text: In my agreement I let the client know that we will not be moving dirty dishes around the kitchen while we clean it. We will wash the dishes which may result in something else not getting done. This puts the ball in their court with clear understanding of what happens if they donâ€™t tidy up. I do not tolerate scope creep at all and this helps them understand they cannot expect extra work without additional compensation. Mostly the clients who consistently leave dishes are grateful for our willingness to do dishes.

Most standard sinks have two basins. We offer 1 sink basin of dishes included in the standard service, more dishes will cost $20 per sink basin. Just having the policy in place avoids showing up to a huge pile of dishes.

text:
Same issue raising its head yet again!  I have never been able to balance jobs and cleaners.

Scheduling has been an ongoing problem with cleaners complaining that the schedule changes too often, and they don't see a week in advance because it changes often.  As soon as they see an open morning or afternoon, they make plans, dr appointment, etc.  So if we try to put in a new deep clean, we have a difficult time getting a team together.  How does everyone else handle this?  I've been in business for going on 8 years, and it's still a problem.  The seasonality of coastal Florida doesn't help!  Thanks for any advice.

topComments.text: We allow our cleaners complete schedule flexibility. Before the start of each week, they tell us what days and hours they'd be willing to work, before we assign them to any cleaning schedule. And once they tell us, we assign their cleaning jobs to match their availability, to which it's much easier for them to commit to showing up and doing amazingly. Cleaners are less likely to leave you hanging if you give them the flexibility that they need and that's something that most work places don't even practice or do. Many comments say how strict they are but it doesn't have to be that way, at least that's what we found out and this method of them choosing their own flexible schedules works well for us.

I've had the same issue with Cleaners making plans and we actually tell them that even if theyre not scheduled a day, to request off so we know in advance not to book anything on that day. 

We start everyone part time so they expect not to have a full schedule as well in the beginning. The longer they stay with us, the more thier schedule will fill.

We actually do allow our cleaners to see months in advance but they know the schedule isnt typically set or confirmed until maybe 1-2 weeks out

text: For companies with an Office Manager and a Field Manger - how do you divide duties between the two? I am in the midst of this management expansion and have run into some issues with overlap. If the office manager does payroll and scheduling, does the cleaner communicate issues to the field manager and then the field manager coordinates rescheduling with the office manager?

topComments.text:
They tag-team *supervising* currently. One is more experienced. 

Depends on the  schedule that day. We perform around 30 cleans a day. Sometimes they are both checking. Sometimes one is checking houses and one may be doing things for me or supervising a large job. 

Just depends on the need that day.

MY time is spent doing estimates and making sure we have plenty of work.

In theory this maybe the right way.

What I found in practice, is that the less points of contact the better. People forget dates times etc changes the more ears and mouths are involved.

Create a form that alerts both or all managers 

The ones it doesnâ€™t concern can disregard but when brought up or in meeting everyone should have seen the alert.

The more eyes on the change the better the less person to person communication the better

text: Has anyone used SendJim or another postal contact software to generate leads?

# Hello! This was sent to me last night by a commercial client of mine. The unit I clean has 6 offices rented by different businesses. I don't clean the individual offices, just common areas. The tenants leave their garbage outside their door to be collected over the weekend.  They sometimes leave all kinds of stuff to be thrown out... medical supplies, office supplies, books, etc. The box she's referring to was on the floor right next to the garbage bag, no note saying "donation". I assumed it was garbage and in the dumpster it went. I told my client what happened and that I would see if it was still there. I felt bad that it was a donation, so I went with gloves and flashlight, ready to do some dumpster diving ðŸ˜‚But it had already been emptied. To be clear, I don't feel I did anything wrong, if she takes donations after hours she should have a better system set up so something like this doesn't happen. But her heading the email "Items Taken" and saying "the cleaning company must have taken it" (instead of the cleaning company may have tossed it) is a red flag to me. I was going to offer to reach out to her personally but with the tone of that email my gut said stay away! lol I texted my client that the box is gone, I assumed it was garbage, I'm sorry for the mix up and I will only remove equipment by her door that is marked as trash going forward. 
# Thoughts or comments? Did I handle this correctly? And if she makes a stink about this (like saying I owe her whatever was in the box) what is the best way to handle it? Thanks for any input :)

text:
**Has This Ever Happened to You?**

You finally do it. You hire a VA.

You're so excited. Finally, someone to help handle the phone calls, the scheduling, the customer emails that eat up your entire day.

**Week 1**: You're optimistic. Training takes longer than expected, but that's normal, right?
**Week 2**: The VA keeps asking questions. Lots of questions. About things you thought were obvious.
**Week 3**: You're spending MORE time managing them than you spent doing it yourself. Something feels wrong.
**Week 4**: A customer calls you directly, frustrated. "Your VA told me the wrong information." You check the messages...they're all over the place. Nothing is how you'd do it.

Now you're stressed, the VA is confused, and you've spent $2,000+ for... what exactly?

**So what went wrong?**

The VA wasn't bad. You just weren't ready.

You were missing the 3 things that make VA relationships actually work:

1. **Documented processes** - The VA was guessing at how you wanted things done
2. **Clear role definition** - "Help with the business" isn't a job description
3.** Communication systems** - You were both winging it daily

The mistake wasn't hiring a VA.

The mistake was hiring BEFORE you were prepared.

This is exactly what we're fixing in the FREE VA Prep Bootcamp (Dec 8-9th).

We'll build those 3 things together BEFORE you waste another dollar on a confused hire.

**Has this happened to you? Comment "YES" below ðŸ‘‡**

(Then I'll send you the bootcamp link so it never happens again)

Stop repeating $8K mistakes. Start preparing properly.

text:
I need help! 

I had a medical facility reach out to me requesting a quote for 2 locations,one was 4,300 sq ft and the other is 7,846 sq ft., M-F after 5pm. I calculated monthly for 3team members $10,100. He comes back 3 days later and only want me to do one location the 4,300sqft. I would send 2 team members now. They are only providing paper products and trash can liners. topComments.text: If you are using your pricing for residential to give a quote you stand a chance of not getting the job. To clean commercial space cost less.

Way off. Our production rate for medical is 2000-2500 sqft per hour per person. So Iâ€™m at 6 hours total. If the two locations are any significant distance per a drive, like 15 minutes or more, Iâ€™d add in that time too, assuming the same person is cleaning both. 

The above also assumes that this is basic medical cleaning and not terminal or aseptic cleaning. 

So at 6 hrs at 5 days paying $20/hr, and assuming a 15% labor tax rate for an employee, Iâ€™m paying in labor $35,880/yr. My supplies would assume that I want to keep supplies and equipment at each location. Assuming an average SOW and due to being small, Iâ€™m at $800/yr for each. Finally, I donâ€™t know your P&L or profit goals but if I aim for a 33% gross profit, thatâ€™s $18,740/yr going into my and my companyâ€™s pocket. 

Add them up and I get $56,220/yr or $4685/mo for both. 

If he wants the 4300 sqft location, In lieu of redoing my math Iâ€™d factor in a percentage. 4300 is 35.4% of both spaces. My price would be approx $1659/mo for that space. Based on your price itâ€™s $3575/mo.

text:
Seeking Guidance: Growing from Solo to LLC 

â€‹Hello everyone! I'm reaching out to this knowledgeable community for a little guidance as I navigate the next phase of my cleaning business, Thrive & Shine Maids.

â€‹I've been working as a solo cleaner for a year, and recently, I took the leap: I brought on my first independent contractor a few months ago and have just finalized the switch to an LLC structure.
â€‹I'm now in that tricky spot between being a one person show and becoming a true business owner. 

Would anyone further along than me be willing to answer a nice list of questions for me? I just ask for you to answer whatever you're comfortable with and at your convenience. Even one solid piece of advice is incredibly helpful!

If you interact with my post, I will send over my questions! Would also love to make a new friend or possibly a mentor! Thanks everyone â˜ºï¸

Have you used Jigsy  for a web-builder ? Would you recommend it for a small business?

I just looking for something affordable, Iâ€™m a solo cleaner  for  now .Any insights or experiences would be greatly appreciated!

text:
What do you say to a customer that booked a deep clean, 900 Sqft house & partial basement. 
2 girls were there for 5 hours, so 10 labor hours of work. 
A lot was done, and the customer recognizes they did amazing work in some areas. But at the same time, she's sending me videos of a paper towel test on her flooring (towel is lightly brown) , there was 1 hair she took a very close up photo on the outside of her tub, and just  little , very petty things. 
She then says she will not be using us anymore for bi-weekly service. Fine. 
But She said she had to "go over things" after they left, but at the same time very satisfied with overall 80% of their work done.  
Is she being unreasonable for nitpicking failing a clean paper towel on mopped floors for a deep cleaning? She does have dogs in the home. 
She also said she expected them to only be there for 2.5-3 hours that her house had no stuck grime or dust etc "it wasn't even that bad" so she doesn't even want to pay for the 10 Labor hours of work.

topComments.text: I cannot tell you how many times a customer thought their house "wasn't that dirty" until they saw it clean. Everybody has a different idea of clean and dirty. Pets will get floors dirty quickly with dirt they track in and dander they drop, so that paper towel test doesn't apply. I live in the desert and dust drifts in and settles on everything five minutes after I've dusted or mopped floors.

text:
Hi everyone - I have a new client (for about 2 months now) and I clean for them bi-weekly.
Initially they said they were very OCD and clean (never trust that) and omg things just keep getting worse 
They don't pickup before I show up so there are toys and clothes everywhere so I'm spending so much time picking up/putting things away 
And the amount of stuff being all over keeps getting out of control 
To top it off, today there was cat vomit and feces in multiple spots plus dirty dishes all over which i would typically load them to the dishwasher but it was already full

Annnnd I wasted so much time looking for the bedsheets because they don't keep it ready for me 

I'm new to the business so I don't have any polices in place yet

Do you guys recommend that I talk to them or just make a policy and have them sign it?

topComments.text: I usually go ahead and take it on the chin the first time (recurring clients only) and then make expectations very clear for next cleaning.

You absolutely must have a list of what is included. And since you normally would wash the dishes they just assumed you would. Give them an inch, theyâ€™re taking ten miles! 

Dear Client,

Attached please find my service checklist of what cleaning items are included in your service for the formerly agreed upon rate. If youâ€™d like to continue adding extras like pick up and dishes it will be xxx additional each service as this adds considerable time on to each cleaning. If youâ€™d like to change sheets ($5 extra per bed) please have the clean sheets out and ready to be changed. Thanks so much!

text:

Currently, I do Zenmaid booking form â€”> text message to confirm walkthrough date and time for quote â€”> in person quote â€”> book the clean.

My pricing is based on square footage for base pricing, then during the walkthrough I decide based on condition how long it will take and add cost accordingly. Would it be smart to offer instant quotes based on square footage and emphasize on the form that its base pricing?

If you were to base quote over the phone and include that price is confirmed upon arrival as a disclaimer on your quote  it could work better 

Same process just split the walkthrough until after they have agreed for you to clean

text: Does anyone have a individual price list sheet that I can edit

ðŸš— Need a little advice from other business owners!

One of my employeesâ€™ cars was hit today while we were at a clientâ€™s home. The client left during the cleaning, and we later noticed the damage after she had already gone. Nothing was said or mentioned before she left.

Iâ€™ve already sent the client a polite message to address it, but now Iâ€™m unsure what to do next â€” should my employee stay at the property or go ahead and leave? I just want to make sure weâ€™re handling this the right way and documenting everything properly.

Has anyone else had this happen before? How did you handle it?

attachments.alt: May be an image of rearview mirror and car

topComments.text: She saying it wasnt her. Offering to let her come check out her car. Employee swears it was done at her property. So now we are wondering if she got a package today.
File a police report for sure and go from there. Let the client know that the car was hit and a report has been filed. Private property is tricky though. In Michigan insurance just sucks now!

text:
Would you guys use a walk-behind scrubber machine for commercial cleaning in a school/childcare?

We are doing many commercial walkthroughs, and as of now we only have dust mops + commercial wet mops.

I am wondering if it is worth the investment.

Just wanted to know your thoughts.

Hey guys, looking for some insight.

Currently transitioning a team member to do only quality control. (Couple days a week)

What has worked for you in structuring this? Pay, tracking there time, etc etc.

Any guidance would be so amazing

topComments.text: I wouldn't make the 1 persons job. All of your cleaners can do this. And as a person who does quality control, it alone does not fill your day.  Best to send your cleaners to jobs and then quakity co trol each other when needed. Not every job needs a quality check. Only with new clients, new cleaners and on complaints

My assistant does this. Sheâ€™s full time and it is a salary position. I do not track her time whatsoever.

She checks where needed, as needed and she is their immediate supervisor.

text: For those of you who have a larger revenueâ€¦ what was your turning point from scraping by to thriving? What did you do differently or better to swing things in your favor?

topComments.text:
Hired more people. Learned more techniques. 

I picked up a client through sheer luck. I quickly learned she was very particular. But we made her happy. She started bragging on us to her friends who would call us and say, â€œIf you can clean for â€œxâ€, I know youâ€™ll do a great job for me!â€

Weâ€™ve been rolling ever since then. We went up to 4 crews for several years. I decided it was too big for my comfort and I downsized in 2020 - we held steady through COVID, that decision was a mental health choice. 

We run a crew of 5 and clean 4-6 homes per day. Today was 6.
Having systems and the right people in the right seat on your team scales your business!

text:
What's your policy on returning company jackets, hoodies, zip ups, tops, hats, etc upon termination. 
Should any of it be returned?

topComments.text: In Canada we have very strict rules on this. We canâ€™t legally hold back pay for these items. I have a kit checklist that they sign off on saying that it must be returned before final pay. But a savvy person could look this up and get away with not returning it. Just be aware of any laws. We have far too many here
Definitely! You risk them wearing them otherwise and representing your brand in a negative way. We hold a small bond from their first pay to ensure their uniforms are returned when they leave.

text: What's one thing that icks you out every single time you clean it? For me it's the inside of the microwave ðŸ¤¢

topComments.text: My thing is pads stuck to the outside of trash bags - wide open. And bars of soap.
I don't bat an eye at most toilets at this point. What I DO bat an eye at is releasing the smell of lasagna from a Wednesday dinner in 2006 in a kitchen ðŸ˜©

text:
Hope everyone is having a wonderful week! Iâ€™d love to get anyoneâ€™s input that has cleaned in a restaurant setting before. We handle plenty of commercial spaces, but this will be our first restaurant. Please note we will not be doing anything in the kitchen area whatsoever. Our only scope will be floors in the main portion of the restaurant and doing the bathrooms. Simple and straight forward. Thank god haha.

-Needing help with commercial/medical office and clinic bids and pricing.  

Hello all!  This is my first post in the group, but I have been soaking up all the knowledge from this fabulous group since my partner and I started in February of this year.  Our business has grown much faster than we ever anticipated and is continuing to grow in residential, commercial, and post-construction clients.  We currently have around 35 recurring clients with $14k in revenue monthly with 5 part time cleaners and 1 part time admin.  Zenmaid has been a huge part of what has helped us stand out among other cleaning services.  So, Iâ€™m thankful for having discovered the program and the resources that have come with it!  We are  beginning to experience more growth on our commercial side but find we are struggling with pricing.  Our typical residential rates are not based on an hourly rate or square footage but sort of a hybrid pricing model while our post-construction is strictly based on square footage.  With commercial clients, especially medical offices and clinics, we are still trying to nail down our method for pricing.  We do not want to use straight hourly rates but find there is a big range between the low/high end on square footage rates in this area.  We are currently bidding on 2 separate commercial locations.  One is a 4300 sq ft medical wellness spa & clinic with 10 hybrid exam/counseling/aesthetic rooms and 8 offices and a spa room.  The other is a 4000 sq ft IT space with around 30 offices.  The facilities are similar in size but entirely different in set up.  Does anyone have a suggestion or be willing to share their method for pricing commercial buildings?  Any insight and info is appreciated!

topComments.text:
Youâ€™re missing a lot of info, itâ€™s ok, we all start somewhere. 

The thing you need to zero in on is production rate. Thereâ€™s a huge variance in commercial that doesnâ€™t exist in residential. Residential rates might be 500-1000 sqft/hr

I have some commercial accounts I expect 4,000-5,000 sqft/hour. 

The amount of people, flooring type, all play a part.

Without more info, Iâ€™d say your 4,300 sq wellness spa is 2-3 hours. The 4k is probably closer to 1.5-2.

Other factors- how often are they being cleaned? If itâ€™s nightly, you can definitely shorten these times, if itâ€™s weekly or more, you probably need to lengthen it.

text:
Good morning â˜ºï¸

Does anyone have a business phone through an app that they really like? I've been using my personal phone but it's time to separate it.

 Any suggestions would be appreciated ðŸ©µ 

Annecita Walker

topComments.text:
Use Dialpad.

I have used Zoom Phone, Quo (formerly OpenPhone), and Dialpad professionally.

Zoom has excellent call quality, but so many frustrations. For example, you can't have a phone menu ("If you're a new customer, press 1...") and send text messages from the same number. You literally need to have two phone numbers-- a main line, and a texting line-- to make this possible. It's full of this kind of friction. It's an afterthought in Zoom's product offerings and it shows.

Quo (OpenPhone) has a wonderful app and good integrations, BUT the call quality is terrible if you're not on WiFi. If you live in a major city with seamless 5G coverage or the phone will only be used by office staff, it can be OK.

Dialpad has a well-designed app and good integrations AND they solved the call quality problem. In areas with low data (5G) coverage, Dialpad uses your phone's cell service for phone calls. Overall, this is the winner.

FYI I don't have a "use my code!" for Dialpad or anything. This has just been a multi-year odyssey for me lol.
We have a business line on our personal phone. So convenient!

text:
Anon for obvious reasons lol. 

My business management is an absolute mess and seriously lacking. 

I opened a business bank account, but it has been intertwinedï¿¼ with my personal way too much at this point, because my business account doesnâ€™t allow me to Zelle people and most of my clients and cleaners use Zelle for payment. 

I had started filing sales and use tax only to realize I didnâ€™t need to and now I need to do an amended return and also figure out how to move forward with that. 

Iâ€™m also very confused and overwhelmed with my Workerâ€™s Compensation audit, as my â€œsubcontractorsâ€ may have been misclassified up to this point. Iâ€™m not even taking on any more big jobs because Iâ€™m so worried about the legal ramifications. 

ï¿¼I also need help learning how to onboard employees  so I can have them working legitimately as W2s. There are other things Iâ€™m sure I need help with too, but I donâ€™t even know what I donâ€™t know. 

Who do I hire to get things in order??? ï¿¼ Is this the job of an accountant? I really need help getting things squared away so I can move forward and keep growing.

topComments.text:
W2 employees are very expensive. 1099 is a very dangerous move and could ruin you if you 1099, they are not true contractors and youâ€™re caught.

Contractors vs employees is very clearly defined now. Not really any gray area. Proceed with 1099 with extreme caution.

For reference, my company performs 600-700 cleans a month.

Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re having trouble. It is very overwhelming owning your first business. 
My first professional hired was an accountant/bookkeeper. By far my best investment. She keeps my books for me, taxes straight, figures out my sales tax and files my business and personal taxes at the end. If you are interested I can send you her info. We also have quarterly meetings to go over my books. (Virtually)
I use travelers for workers comp in Pa and we are signed up for pay as you go. At the end of the week you enter your payroll and it tells you what you owe. The audit comes out to zero at the end of the year. I was
Burned MANY times w that. Liability is also based on your payroll so be careful w that as well.  Iâ€™ve dealt w a couple of shady agents in the past and I didnâ€™t fully understand the insurance and was entirely too trusting. My accountant does my insurance audit at the end of the year. 
I also use a small local payroll company so they deal w all of the payroll taxes and all of that. 
Lastly, make sure your subcontractors have their own insurance and are actually subcontractors and not employees. An accountant can help you to properly classify. 
Good luck to you- it seems overwhelming but once you hire an accountant to figure all of this out- you can get back to growing your company without all of this worry.

text:
âœ¨ Looking for a little advice from fellow cleaners or business owners! âœ¨
Right now, most of my work is focused on Airbnb cleanings, but Iâ€™ve noticed our area is becoming pretty saturated, and bookings have started to slow down. Because of that, Iâ€™m thinking about transitioning more into residential cleaning â€” but Iâ€™m not quite sure the best way to go about it.
For my Airbnb clients, Iâ€™ve always charged a flat rate, which works really well. But with residential cleanings, I know every home and clientâ€™s needs can vary a lot, which makes me wonder if an hourly rate might make more sense.
For those of you who do residential work â€” whatâ€™s worked best for you? Flat rate or hourly? And any tips on transitioning from Airbnb to residential?
Appreciate any advice or insight! ðŸ’™

topComments.text:
We do flat rate based on our production rate and an estimated time it will take to complete the job. Ask 5000 questions then ask moreðŸ˜‚ 

I suggest charging hourly until you know your production rate so that you donâ€™t get stuck at a 12 -14 hour job that you quoted flat rate at $325. 

Create client guidelines and have them sign them before you ever step foot in their property. 

Use checklist for your client to see what youâ€™re going to do and for you/your cleaners to follow. 

Up your communication - residential clients tend to like more communication than other clients. 

Automate your scheduling so there is no double booking or over booking. 

Allow extra time in your estimates until you get a good rhythm/flow and until you know your production rate. 

Decide what task you are
Willing to do and what you arenâ€™t. Some examples: are you willing to do dishes (spell it out exactly what youâ€™re willing to do whether itâ€™s only put away or load and start the dishwasher or if youâ€™re willing to do two sinks plus a countertop full of dirty dishes), laundry (fold and put away only or wash dry fold and put away or stain treatments, sorting). 
Are you willing to clean litter boxes or pick up animal feces/ clean up urine?
What will you bring and what does the client need to supply? 
Will you use your vacuum on flooring that has been soiled by pets? 
Are you comfortable cleaning with pets and humans home? 

Do you have any allergies to things people often have in their home? 

Whatever you answer is to all of these - go make a guideline about it bc the client will need you to spell it out for them. It protects you when you have boundaries in place. Things go much smoother when you have a clear idea of what youâ€™re walking into.

1. Get very specific on what you will and will not do if you're taking on residential. 
2. We personally do a Flat rate, but we use our average production rate to calculate the price.
3. Payment before or after? We do after but lots of others do before.
4. Have terms & conditions sent to all customers, it will save you in certain situations.
5. Following up with each client for reviews and for recurring services periodically.

text:
Need some advice, cleaners!
I have a client who is the mother of a family friend. She normally pays a flat $120 for her clean, which is usually about 3 hours. This week, they had the area rugs from 3 rooms sent out for cleaning, which left the floors bare with lots of residue from the rug backing. I had to vacuum and mop multiple times where I normally just vacuum.

On top of that, she had used rug tape to hold them in place. She pulled up the tape in the foyer and asked me to get the sticky off. I told her I wasnâ€™t prepared for that type of job and didnâ€™t have the right supplies (like Goo Gone). She was upset and asked me to try anyway. I had a green Scotch-Brite pad, so I used that on the tile and it worked. Once she saw that, she started pulling tape up in the other rooms and said, â€œGreat, you can do these rooms too.â€

That turned into an extra 1.5 hours of scrubbing floors. She still paid me the regular $120 since I donâ€™t charge hourly, I charge per job. Honestly, if I had known in advance, this would have been at least a $180 job.

What should I have done or said differently in this situation? Would you have stopped and set a new price before continuing? How do you handle things like this when youâ€™re put on the spot?

topComments.text: Hi Cynthia, Iâ€™m totally OK with it for this time because you are a family friend and I think you are amazing and wouldnâ€™t want to make any sort of unnecessary increase in price that you werenâ€™t aware of so donâ€™t worry about this one but going forward the job that I did today wouldâ€™ve cost a regular Client $180 because of the extra time that I spent on the floor, scrubbing all my hands and knees so the next time if we add anything like that in or it has to go over the regular charge I will have to charge a little bit extra, but I just wanted to let you know in advance so thereâ€™s no surprises. I hope youâ€™re having a great day. See you next Tuesday. ðŸ˜Š

You already answered your own question.

Yes you are the boss!  If the owner of the business feels like the price is wrong it should be adjusted on the spot.

You know the answer

OR

You are comfortable working 4.5 hours for $120

This comes out to $26.67 per hour.

text:
Interested in peoples views.  It seems US business is primed for growth but in the UK growth is not welcomed by our government AT ALL , in fact you are penalised so much millions of businesses purposely limit their growth to stay under the VAT threshold ( Its a tax at 20% of revenue that annihilates customer facing businesses). I asked Chat to run a comparable of my company and it said : Do you want me to also run a **direct UK vs US side-by-side table** so you can clearly see how profits diverge as you scale? That way youâ€™ll see exactly how VAT in the UK eats into growth vs US payroll tax structure.

Entrepreneurs are leaving the UK in droves, we have the biggest exodus on the planet second only to China, 9,500 left in the last year. I'm thinking I may have to leave the UK altogether if I want to be able to grow a business. Its so disheartening to know your government actively doesn't want businesses to grow or take on staff as the bottleneck at the threshold has just been growing into the millions for years..... the government must know about it and see that that tax is a huge barrier to growth. Which suggests its a purposeful barrier. What are your thoughts? If you are in a different country is there a blocker to your growth by the government ?

topComments.text: I hear you it is crippling in the UK ðŸ˜¤

I'm British-American and grew up in both countries, so this speaks directly to me as an entrepreneur. I've thought many times about starting a business back in blighty, but it's just extremely unappealing when you have access to the US market already. In fact I briefly ran a software company there, but it was just unnecessarily difficult to meet all the local regs and it didn't work out in part because of the different business climate (not only that, but it really played a role). 

You can make it work and it's still a great place to start a business compared to most countries, but it's not a great place to grow a business profitably. You'll also only get access to a fraction of the funding that a US startup will have access to if you go the funding route.

text:
Q4 is here!! 
Whatâ€™s ONE thing you want to get accomplish before year end?!

What are you running for your budget on Indeed?  Are you happy with your current strategy.  I'm not pumped so far but maybe its my budget, my area, or my copy on my job post.  Not sure.  Looking to dial it in.

topComments.text:
The trick we've found with Indeed is to sponsor the job(s) for 1 month but then we post the Indeed links on FB and boost it there too. 

We use FB to pull people to our Indeed Ad.

Itâ€™s horrible ROI!!!! I complained to them countless times but got nowhere. Just paid $500 for about 6 people that showed up.
I have it set to $45 promote or whatever corny thing they say and run it for 1 week.

As bad as it is, still 100x better the zip recruiter but very expensive.

text:
As someone who has been in the business more than 20 years some of the things that drive me the most crazy are as follows...who else feels the same and what are some of your pet peeves?

 

1) You know we are coming..the entire house should be ready...don't be in the way, don't try to pick up or shower....cook etc once we get there.

2) Put your pets up or out...many times we can't even get in the door with our equipment and supplies without your dog(s) underfoot or trying to run out..jumping on us, barking it's head off..I have almost fallen down the stairs several times because your dog is racing me upstairs...we are dusting and vacuuming and mopping and they are running around leaving footprints and dropping hair..

3) Moveouts: don't try to schedule your cleaning for the same day you are moving IT NEVER goes well. Your cleaning is set for a certain amount of time we are not going to be there all day working around you

4) Clear out...if you want to be home don't expect us to clean with you in the room...go to another part of the house and give us some space..and do not follow me around and watch me...I will let you know very quickly I will not clean that way

5) check people: if you have regular service, you are home, you pay by check don't wait til we say "ok, we are finished" to write that dang check...have it ready to go

I could go on and on but I won't...what drives yall nuts?

topComments.text: i felt all of them. i need a part two

For me is when they choose my day to have people coming I'm to do work.
I work around them. I couldn't careless.
5 hours I'm out of there

text: How many hours per month is ZM saving you? ðŸ™ŒðŸ¼âœ¨

topComments.text: Average 15-20 hours per month

It varies but every month I have total peace of mind. Its when a staff member is leaving and you need to reallocate its so so easy and saves hours of admin...so on those months I save even more time. The best part of my business is actually ZM !

text:
how would you handle a client who homeschools her 2 littles works from home and her husband also works from home. so they are always there and in use of the house.

I am trying to clean while they are making food in the kitchen or sitting at the dining table doing schoolwork. constant in and out of the bathrooms that i just cleaned and so on.

this last time there were crab apples spread out all over the counter in the kitchen along with food spills,dishes and whatnot. the client wanted me to just clean the counters off. ok no problem i did that, then was asked to clean master room so i went to the master to clean that but all personal items were everywhere the kids items also. 
i dusted made the bed and cleaned the floor this is what she wanted. I then went back into the kitchen to a complete mess while i was in the bedroom they started making apple sauce out of the crab apples. she asked me to do the kitchen floor before i left so i had to do them around her and her child. anyways long story short i left feeling like i did nothing. 

idk if this was a rant or not but what would you do?

topComments.text:
Have you been open with her and let her know how you are feeling and that you would like to service her better see if the both of you can't come up with something that works for you both? If and explain that if xyz can't be meet that you will have to increase her cost of cleaning because xyz than put it in writing and you both sign the new service agreement. 
I think it's something like 95% of business problems can be fixed if only we would have the hard conversions.
There is NO silver bullet. Unfortunately. Raise the price and continue doing what you are doing.

text: Heller, everyone nice to meet yaâ€™ll. Iâ€™m Ash, Iâ€™ve started my little business and have it going fairly well but Iâ€™m still having trouble with finding enough clients for the whole week. As you can see I have ADORABLE 6 year boy child and a supportive husband who gives me the push I need when I feel like Iâ€™m failing. If yall have any advice for advertising, along with any advice in  general especially about book keeping Iâ€™d greatly appreciate it. Iâ€™ve asked a few people, and none of the few people honestly know themselves. This is a new big adventure for myself and family, and I truly want to succeed. I want to show my older children, that yes even if you had a rough past/life that we are capable of turning our lives around and breaking old cycles, and making something of ourselves. That it is never too late to chase a dream, and most importantly, when we start something (like I have with my small business) you donâ€™t give up on it because it gets a bit difficult. With that being said one of my difficulties is asking for help/advice, but Iâ€™m realizing now that if I donâ€™t reach out I wonâ€™t be able to succeed. topComments.text: Follow the ZenMaid chats and podcasts DAILY! They are GOLD.
Your questions are TOO broad and complex. Try to make a list of specific questions. Will get more golden nuggets this way. ðŸ«¶

text: Do people here record their calls? I want to start recording our calls, but we are in a state (Illinois) that requires "two-way" consent, so we need the other side to be ok with it. Is anyone else in a two-way consent state (about a dozen states, including California and Florida) that record calls? How do you go about it?

topComments.text: Marko Lazarevic Are you using a software to do so? I imagine they'll have all of this covered on their end (also putting the liability on them). And yes, as Viv Doolan mentioned, it can be covered in the intro message.

Could this not be covered in the starting message ? Where the start of the calls says calls are recorded could you say by continuing the call you are consenting to being recorded and if they don't want to be recorded give them an email option ? That would save a tonne of work if you can do it that way

text:
Hiring percentages?????
My current hiring stats

mostly from Indeed

Out of 

100 applicants

60% respond to us on the platform 

45% setup in person interview

15% actually show up to interview

7-10% we offer a position 

Please shed some light on this.  Are these numbers what you track during your hiring?

What steps do you follow?  Phone, in person, zoom etc?

This is our BOTTLENECK in our business.

topComments.text: My 5 cents: you MUST have a chart where you put people who dont show up etc.  Because they WILL apply again.

Hiring should never stop. Itâ€™s an ongoing thing that you will need to continue to do for the duration of your business. Pre-screening is great and we of course block out the no-shows as well. Iâ€™ve developed a very strong list of interview questions using ChatGPT that seemed to weed out the knuckleheads. We also have great trainers that are able to spot red flags and call them out to us on day one so we donâ€™t waste our time. Unfortunately, you will always be hiring and you will always be firing in this industry.  

I have a saying, written right on my whiteboard and big bold black letters. Hire fast, and fire faster!

topComments.text: Question: how many of your Connections are located within your service area?
Do you have a LinkedIn page for your company? I post on our business page and then share it on my personal LinkedIn page. I create them on Canva and post them to our socials- FB, IG and LinkedIn.

text: Who uses zenmaids for 1099 companies. Do uou maintain there schedule within zenmaids? What's you payout frequency? Tell me things you wish you had known before hand

topComments.text: I'm working on opening a domestic referral agency next year. I will use ZenMaid. The 1099 employees will receive an invitation so they can accept or decline jobs. The only thing with ZenMaid, the cleaner sees a message that "the employer" will schedule the service. I'm in California, and we can't have that! I had to go to Canva to create my own invitation. Every time, I'll have to change the name and information on it because ZenMaid won't make a coding change to customize the cleaner invitation. Other than that, it's perfect!

I run 40 1099 contractors - they create their schedules we input into zenmaid. Itâ€™s possible.
Be mindful of your state laws and consult with a business attorney to make sure your processes and paperwork are correct legally.

text:
Adding last minute cleanings...
Ok, we clean for a big company that has apartment buildings. Ive had this account for 11 years, its our bread & butter, truly. With that said, we get move outs thrown to us often with a days notice, sometimes if its a slow day we can do them that afternoon. 
But when i add these apartments (2b/1b) my cleaners are livid. The indeed ad said 8-5p Monday-Friday. 

Ex: yesterday it was a very slow day due to a cancel. This company messaged me tuesday night so i added an apt in the morning... the attitude i was given about it from the cleaners was insane. BUT they were going to be off work around 12pm otherwise... do i have a right to add things? How do you all go about this? Im tired of getting attitudes especially when this was clearly stated in job ads & new hire paperwork that things can be added if completion is before hours on their availability.

topComments.text: If itâ€™s a team of employees maybe one or a or afew are doing more of the work than the others and thatâ€™s why they hate doing them ? I would ask why it bothers them to see if itâ€™s something u can fix other than that u have the right to do this and id would be appreciative if my boss gave me more hours on a short day

Ok so I place "fake" clients on my schedule where I might be able to add a booking + on call shifts because we get requests for last minute clients ALL the time. 99% of the time it works out that we get a booking. When we place them on call they usually ask for the time off instead.  The faux client works and It's under my Opa's name who. passed some time ago and gives me all the feels to have him assit me in this manner. 

The times we don't get a booking- "the client cancels" and they are more than happy to have the time off. 

I hope this helps.

text:
Hiring location question
We run a commercial/ residential cleaning company in Vermont.  We have a few employees and run the business out of our home.

Nice home office, supply racks in garage.

Where do you hold job interviews?

We usually meet for interviews at a local Starbucks.    

Iâ€™m starting to think that I would like to change/ improve this.  A little nervous whether inviting potential employees to my house looks unprofessional, even if it is an office within my home.

Any ideas?

topComments.text:
Do you have a membership to your local chamber of commerce? When we started we would hold things there in the free meeting rooms. And one of our commercial clients let us host interviews in a meeting room.

Do you have any co-working spaces near by where you can rent 1 office? 

I think year 2 or 3 we got our first office.
Applicants can be nuts. 100% DONT do your house. In fact, move your office/supplies to storage/office asap. No-one should know where you live.

text: I'm new to bidding commercial work. It is a church that is approximately 8,000sq ft. Is $450 too high? I'm figuring $75 an hour for 6 hours 2 or 3 employees. How would I figure a price break down by room? Any help will be greatly appreciated.

images.alt: May be an image of text
May be an image of text

topComments.text: Churches are my jam. We do a lot of them. I'm completely opposite from Samantha. It won't take 3 hours with 1 person. $450 is too high. However, that's for a normal cleaning. The SOW is normal based on your pictures except for the strip/wax and carpet extraction. Those aside, my price would be lower. If they want the price for the work folded in, then my price would be much higher (depends on the frequency).

I once had a contract to clean a church. Something to take into consideration is they are a non-profit and limited on what they can spend. It's hard to think of doing all that work when they have to watch their expenses.

text: domestic weekly clean... client had asked us to bleach thr grout between tiles..  would you change more? ( I.e state this comes under a deep clean as using harsher chemicalsetc) or would you just include as part of routine donestic clean , say every few weeks

topComments.text: I would not charge more to spray bleach on the grout. If it needs full grout scrubbing every time then yes.
Why do they want that would be a consideration. Is it mildewed? Is it discolored? Just because?

text: For those paying employees a flat rate per space cleaned, about what percentage are you paying them?

topComments.text: I am good with sales. Some of my clients are happy paying $60-$80 an hour. That means my techs will be making about $30-40 an hour! ( I charge a flat rate based roughly on the time it takes to complete the job). I also have clients that pay much less, elderly, disabled. Iâ€™m concerned these clients wonâ€™t get the same attention. Does it have to be a straight across the board percentage?

text:
Hey everyone! Iâ€™m starting a cleaning business and Iâ€™m stuck on the hardest partâ€¦ picking a name.

topComments.text: You will find out that employees are the hardest part of a cleaning business. Pick a name so you can have a website with that name. How about your location like Motown Maids Clearwater Cleaning, look for good Alliteration. Notice how easy it is to remember a good name.

text:
Im having a huge issue with travel with some newer girls. The same route we've had for years that has taken 17 minutes to drive to is now taking 50 minutes or travels that took 25 minutes are taking over an hour. Theyre acting like I'm wrong but i have driven these riutes for 12 years!.. how in the world do you fix this or pay this? I pay hourly and i just cannot pay these travel times! 

This morning a travel that is 6.7 miles thru back roads, typically takes 10 minutes.. took 47 minutes! We do not live in a huge city with crazy traffic at 10am on country roads. It makes no sense.

topComments.text: We require a photo of so called traffic or anything out of norm. If not provide we pay the minutes we know it takes since we have had same routes for years

Issue a new directive/ policy

You get paid based on mileage + 10% of estimated time

This way if they drive at a brisk pace ( not speeding) they are actually making more money.

If they drive too slow or stop thatâ€™s OK but they are in their own time.

text: I'm moving out of state from my company and looking into registered agents. Does anyone have experience with Northwest Registered Agents?   Also, will I also need a virtual business address or is that not really necessary? Thanks for any insight!

Hello All.
Checking in here first . Iâ€™ve hired an accountant as we have gotten big enough that I need a clear financial plan.

Iâ€™m old school and like to handle all things myself and an excel spreadsheet, but I realize I need to get with the times.

I am currently invoicing through Zenmaid, funds collect in square space, and then I transfer funds over to Quickbooks.

Iâ€™m wondering if I can invoice through Zenmaid and it go through quickbooks and cut out square space or any other credit card companies .
(So invoice and funds collct straight to QB) 

Also, does anyone use the invoicing system that is set up to go out automatically? 

Looking to streamline it to make it flow, but Iâ€™m nervous that it wonâ€™t be in my control .

Thanks so much in advance for helping this weary and novice business owner !

topComments.text:
I was using Zenmaid to invoice and I use QuickBooks. I decided to invoice directly from QuickBooks because I had to enter the sale info into QuickBooks from Zenmaid. Once the funds came in, I had to receive the payment.  It was double the work. 

Now I send the invoice, the customer has an option to tip, they pay and QuickBooks automatically receives and records the transaction so I don't have to.  It deposits it into my bank account.  It's easy and my customers like it.

You can intergrate zenmaid to to qbo using zapier but Iâ€™m not sure how seamless that would be. It may be double the work. I would just invoice through quickbooks if all your accounting is done there.

text:
Hello everyone, just wondering if you can give me sample bid showing how you would calculate labour, hours, and services for a facility of this size maybe just roughly just an idea hehe thank you very much ðŸ˜Š the supplies and equipment not included 

The gallery is an 86,000 sq. ft. facility with 32,000 sq. ft. of exhibition space over three floors, including offices, storage, Shop, a 150-seat theatre, and event spaces.

    â€¢    Daily cleaning (5 days/week): Sweeping, vacuuming, mopping, dusting, restroom care, trash/recycling removal, and interior glass cleaning.
    â€¢    One day deep cleaning (gallery closed): Exhibition areas, offices, classrooms, basement floor polishing (monthly), carpet washing (monthly), and detailed high-traffic area care.
    â€¢    Office cleaning: 4th floor (~20â€“30 desks)
    â€¢    Storage cleaning: Separate building (~5 mins away), ~10 hrs/month

Cleaning would be performed 9 AMâ€“3 PM with 2â€“3 staff.

So maybe 514 hours total monthly just estimate

topComments.text:
I'm commercial only and there's not enough info to come up with a price. But speaking in generalities....

If I had an 86K gallery, I'd start by asking why they want daytime. There are people there viewing whatever....doing a full clean in the daytime would limit that experience. Plus once you clean, then it's dirty again by the end of the day. Are they looking for a porter service maybe? 

If indeed they want janitorial, then I'd narrow down that time. You're guessing 12-18 hours. That's a really broad range. You'd want to nail that down to your best guess based on your experiences and production rate.

Our production rate for a museum is 4000 sqft per hour per person. but that's vacuuming, restrooms, cleaning display glass, etc. That would place it to 22 hours rounded up. That's far cry from 12-18. But I also suspect you saw it already and have more details than my guess.

I'd then calculate my labor. I'd take the hours and multiply that by days per week, weeks per year, and the rate I want to pay to come up with a gross wage. I'd then multiply that by my labor tax rate. 

I never let my clients provide supplies or equipment and I'd budget $1500/yr for the main building and $500/yr on the offsite. This would get me a vacuum at each location, mop bucket at each location, and chemicals for each...so this way I'm not moving things around.

Finally, after I added labor and supplies together, I'd factor in a gross profit (overhead + net profit). If I had a goal of 33% GP, I'd multiply my labor and supplies by 1.5 to get a total contract amount. I'd divide by 12 for a monthly rate.
24 thousand for those hours.

text:
Commercial cleaning! 

My business is moving into accepting commercial accounts, with that being said I know very little about this specific industry. 

Supplies: what supplies do you bring to large buildings? Assuming our residential setup would be tough to lug around 

Subcontracting vs Employees?

I have one interested account, 5 buildings, 2x a week, hoping for them all to be done the same night- which would mean hiring multiple people. 
 I do not have any commercial cleaners for those hours at this time.

They are hoping to give us a test run & have accepted a bid for a deep clean (18 man hours) of one of the buildings. 

I plan to participate in the deep clean for educational purposes, but I am not available to help with cleanings weekly on the hours requested, so I would be relying on staff to do so- which brings me fear of call ins.

topComments.text:
Commercial is easy, repetitive and not many surprises. Staff tends to prefer it because itâ€™s simpler than residential and the hours/job is the same every week. 

We leave supplies on site for the team. They bring in steady income and rarely let go if you provide a reliable clean.

Weâ€™re commercial only. 

We donâ€™t lug around supplies. We leave them on site. So much easier. 

Subs vs employees? Depends on your goals. If you want to train them, provide those supplies, have them rep your brand, and control how long they work and when they show/leave before going to the next location you need employees. 

If you donâ€™t want to buy any supplies, you donâ€™t want to mess with training, you want to avoid expenses like labor taxes or added insurance costs, or donâ€™t care when they do the work, subs are the way to go. 

Pros and cons to both. Half of our labor in our last biz were employees. Today I use all subs.

text:
We have two types of staff with different responsibilities.
* **Office managers**: They create quotes and schedule cleans, so they need access to pricing.
* **Shift leaders**: They assign crews each day, but they should not see pricing.

The issue is that the system only seems to offer two roles: *office manager* or *cleaner*. To give shift leaders scheduling access, I have to set them as office managers. However, this makes it impossible to restrict their access to pricing. The settings for office managers are all-or-nothing: if pricing is blocked, then even the people who actually need to see it (the true office managers) canâ€™t.

Has anyone figured out a workaround? For example, can someone be set as an admin with full access while others are limited to scheduling without seeing pricing?

topComments.text: Out of curiosity, why should shift leaders not see pricing?

Our office manager assigns the crews as well to avoid favoritism with jobs that are easier or customers who tip. Shift leaders clean and do the quality checks at each job. They see the price because they collect payments from those who pay by check or in cash.

Did I Overprice?

Hi everyone, Iâ€™d love some feedback on a bid I just put together.

The Building:
 â€¢ 5,100 sqft new build office
 â€¢ 1 kitchen/lounge/dining area
 â€¢ 2 restrooms + single stall shower/washroom
 â€¢ Downstairs: 4 desk spaces in open floor plan with polished concrete + 1 private office
 â€¢ Upstairs: 1 private office, mostly open space, and a large conference room with table/chairs, long sink and cabinets
 â€¢ New build but located in a dusty area with another large office going up next door, so dust may be ongoing

Client Expectations:
The decision-maker said:
 â€¢ Employees are expected to clean up after themselves
 â€¢ Doesnâ€™t need super deep cleaning every visit
 â€¢     Client provides their own bathroom restock supplies
 â€¢ Okay with us rotating focus areas if needed
 â€¢ Considering weekly or biweekly service

My Proposal:
Weekly Service
â€¢ $433.50 per clean
â€¢ $1,878.50 monthly flat
â€¢ Based on $0.085 per sqft
Biweekly Service
â€¢ $535.50 per clean
â€¢ $1,160.20 monthly flat
â€¢ Based on $0.105 per sqft

Our labor comes out to $25/hr. We aim for 45% labor- making our hourly goal $55.56. Iâ€™ve estimated 8 hours per clean, but Iâ€™m thinking this may be overkill for the needs of the space. Even if we spent 8 hrs that would put our rate at $54.21- so the rate would be justified. 
Is my thinking of the numbers correct here?

Does this seem way overpriced for Central Washington? Iâ€™m trying to balance fair pricing with making sure labor, overhead, and profit margins are covered, but I donâ€™t want to scare them off if I overshot.

text:
# ðŸ“šMost Business Books Are Trash. Here Are the 9 That Actually Work for Cleaning Companies

Look, I've probably read 100+ business books over the past 10 years of building and scaling cleaning businesses. 

**Most were garbage**. 

But a handful literally changed everything. 

Everyone's posting about the latest software, AI tools, and complex systems right now. And yeah, that stuff matters eventually. But honestly? For most of us, going back to the fundamentals is the most powerful thing we can do. 

Sometimes the biggest breakthroughs come from the basics we've forgotten or never learned properly.

Since I see so many new cleaning business owners asking "where do I even start?", here's a real, impactful list of books that will get you further than almost any course will. 

Not the books that sound impressive on a shelf, but the ones that actually moved the needle when I was grinding through my first few years.

**THE PRACTICAL STUFF (Read These First)**

**ðŸ“•Profit First - Mike Michalowicz** This should be book #1, period. Before you read anything about marketing or sales, read this. Why? 

Because I see cleaning business owners hit $30K/month and still be broke because they don't understand cash flow. This book saved my ass in year 2 when I was making good money but had nothing in the bank. Set up his workflow (it takes 30 minutes and will save your business).

**â° The 4-Hour Workweek - Tim Ferriss**
I know, I know the title sounds like BS. But ignore that. The automation and delegation principles in here are GOLD for service businesses. This book taught me to stop being a slave to my schedule and learn how to always focus on the big wins. The key isn't working 4 hours (that's real but mostly marketing fluff), but rather teaching you how to work ON your business, not IN it.

**ðŸ“Š The 12 Week Year - Brian Moran** Forget annual goals, they're useless for local businesses. This book breaks everything into 12-week sprints with specific metrics. I used this for years to track customer retention, team performance, revenue per route. Game changer for staying focused and actually hitting targets instead of just hoping things work out.

**ðŸ’¸ I Will Teach You To Be Rich - Ramit Sethi** Not sexy and comes with another stupid title, but crucial. As entrepreneurs we're great at making money, but terrible at managing it personally. This automates your personal finances so you can focus on growing the business. Set it and forget it. No book has been more impactful to my personal finances than this one. 

**ðŸ”§ The E-Myth - Michael Gerber** The classic, how can I not include it? Most cleaning business owners are technicians who think they're entrepreneurs. You started because you're good at cleaning, but running a business is totally different. This shows you how to build systems so the business runs without you. It's essential if you want to scale past being a one-person operation.

**THE MINDSET STUFF **

**ðŸ’ª Antifragile - Nassim Taleb** It's a heavy read, but worth it. Our businesses get hit with constant chaos from team no-shows, to supply shortages, difficult customers, and economic downturns. This book teaches you how to get STRONGER from stress, not just survive it. It really changed how I think about preparing for problems.

**ðŸš§ The Obstacle Is The Way - Ryan Holiday** We all face the same obstacles: pricing pressure, labor shortages, demanding customers. Instead of just enduring them, Ryan's book shows you how to turn obstacles into competitive advantages. I've found this helpful in all areas of my life and is a book I gift to others.

**ðŸ† Built to Sell - John Warrillow** This book is a treasure trove of insights, even if you never plan to sell. I've used the principles to help prep 3 different cleaning businesses for sale, and the framework completely changes how you think about building your company. It forces you to create systems that work without you, standardize everything, and focus on recurring revenue. The beauty is that a "sellable" business is also a profitable, scalable, less-stressful business. Essential read.

**ðŸ‘‘ Meditations - Marcus Aurelius** 2,000-year-old wisdom from a Roman Emperor that still applies to us mortals today. When your best cleaner quits via text or a customer is screaming about something ridiculous, this book keeps you centered.

**Here's what I want to know from the other experienced Zenmaiders in the group:**

Which book actually changed how you run your cleaning business? Not just inspired you for a week, but made you DO something different that improved your results?

**And for the newer owners:** what's your biggest challenge right now? Maybe there's a book that directly addresses it.

Drop your recommendations below and let's help the newer guys n' gals out. 

#CleaningBusiness #BusinessBooks #Entrepreneurship #SmallBusiness #ServiceBusiness

This is how you help new businesses.  This is great.  A couple of new ones to me. I look forward to adding them to my reading.  Thank you for sharing.

text: When you got your llc how did you go about getting it ? Did you go through a website or through your state ? Also what all did you get when doing your llc any add ons ?

topComments.text: I filed it myself through the state of Oregon website. I know there are services offering add ons where they will file annual reports and other things for you, but they often charge huge markups for this. If you have the funds and prefer to automate â€” go ahead! But if youâ€™re running on a budget, itâ€™s not difficult to file yourself.

You usually file it with your state first.  Once it goes through, then you get an EIN number from the IRS. You'll need an EIN # to open a bank account and get insurance. 

Be sure to do your research on any local and state taxes you'll have to pay.  Good luck.
