What kind of call-out policy do you all have in place for your cleaners?

Right now, I donâ€™t use a point system. My team is just told to call if they need to call out. Lately though, I feel like itâ€™s happening a little more often than Iâ€™d like.

Iâ€™ve been debating a policy where if someone calls out, they automatically lose the following day too. My thought process is that if theyâ€™re truly sick, it gives them extra recovery time. And if theyâ€™re not, it creates a consequence for calling out unnecessarily. I havenâ€™t decided if I want to implement this or go in a different direction though.

Most of the time, even if someone calls out, my other cleaners can handle the day unless itâ€™s a big job or Iâ€™ve overbooked myself. It usually only becomes a real issue if I get multiple call-outs at once.

For context, I donâ€™t work in the field as often anymore â€” my main focus is managing remotely, marketing, and handling leads. So I also feel like I could work that following day if needed and I don't already have a big clean in place.

text: Has anyone in here started a cleaning business without the intention of ever cleaning yourself or hiring employees, but rather focusing on marketing and funneling all of your jobs to another trusted company?

topComments.text: Yep - been doing it for nearly 10 years now, only ever cleaned 2 houses in that time. There are many others who do the same now, it's a pretty standard type of cleaning business these days.

Me! I know some people say itâ€™s a scam, but itâ€™s really not. It all comes down to the company and the business model. For us, turnover is actually very low but we are also extremely picky with who we partner with. Most of the contractors we part ways with are either moving or itâ€™s due to quality issues and even then, they often reach back out for another chance.

Weâ€™ve been in business for 7 years and the cleaners we work with have been with us for years. It truly is a partnership. There are so many people who love the cleaning side of things but donâ€™t want to deal with the business aspects. Thatâ€™s where we step in. We bring in the jobs, handle customer service, deescalations, billing, invoicing, and marketing to keep the work steady. They just focus on doing the job well.

At the end of the day, weâ€™re all a team working together to make sure everything runs smoothly. And honestly, before I started this, I didnâ€™t even know what a magic eraser was and to this day, I still donâ€™t know how to use one ðŸ˜….

text: What is everyoneâ€™s gloves policy? Every room? Just bathrooms? One set for each bathroom?

I only require them for toilets because it's easier to enforce changing gloves than it is washing hands. I highly encourage gloves through the whole clean, but if they want dry cracking hands, that's their decision lol

text: I am struggling figuring out the best way to split up the schedule in order to grow? I currently have 4 cleaners including myself that work during the dayâ€¦ i have been hesitating to grow or change anything because we have a great system but i know it would be beneficial if i take a leap and split us up.. Just struggling on the scheduling part of everything. Help!! All advice welcome.

topComments.text: Hi Anna, I just wanted to jump in here and add my opinion since I think I may be able to help you. A lot of answering this question would depend on knowing how your scheduling your homes now - For example, are they used to four people or three vs two, are they all stacked with clients firm on the days they like, etc. While it is generally good advice to say you should leave the field, I don't believe this is true if: 1. Your are new at cleaning, being a business owner, or both. Unless you already know what it takes to run a team and it doesn't sound like your dead set on that even being for you, I don't see why you would leave the field. It's profitable to work for yourself, especially at the stage you're at now. Just know, that if you add even two or three more people as you make that leap, what you do for the team size you have now won't work for the team size you will have. Always be updating and plugging away and making the inside of your business better (Think SOP, Customer Acquisition, Hiring Funnels, Etc) then be adding clients and doing a good job as you go so you can maintain retention and pay the people your hiring while covering the cost of the needed extra supply. I just signed a lease for my first commercial office (been running this out of my home) and im four and half years in with 16-20 employees over the last year. But if you don't want to be a CEO, absolutely do not step away from cleaning. At least not until you know if that's what you want.

You already said you know it would be beneficial for the cleaning techs to split up. So, you've answered your question. I think It's just the doubt creeping in about the logistics of the changes that would need to be made. Don't doubt yourself. You can do this.

text: Iâ€™m looking at bidding on a couple car dealerships in my small town. What should be my man-hour rate for a 6x per week clean. Each cleaning would take us roughly 2 hours. The current company they have (which they are highly displeased with) is charging $2500 monthly.

topComments.text:
Your rate needs to be based off your P&L and your local labor market. I donâ€™t know your expenses. 

At $2500/month the current company is charging $96.23/visit. Divided by 2 hours thatâ€™s $48.11 per hour. 

$48 is a solid rate for most commercial cleaning companies, esp. for 6x. 

People donâ€™t buy based on price. They buy on value. You could charge more or less and still do well.

text: Hi Iâ€™m looking at my first daycare cleaning contract. What is the best way to properly clean and sanitise the space? Sheâ€™s requesting once a week, for about 2000 sq ft. Pricing and any tips welcome!

topComments.text: Bleach

you can't use sos pads or steel wool on porcelain that's where the stain is from. Depending on how hard you scrubbed it may just be residue from steel wool or you may have damaged it. I'd recommend lightly scrubbing with a wet pumice stone to try to remove it. On porcelain you can use pumice stone lightly but not steel wool.

text: Hi everyone. I have my first walk through for commercial client coming up. Itâ€™s a 5000sqft dental clinic. Can I have any pointers on how to approach the walkthrough, specific questions to ask, things to look out for? Also, if anyone has resources like checklists that they can share, I would appreciate!

topComments.text:
That's great ðŸ‘ 

Thank you

If I added them as a lead, and marketed to them, and they want a quote to where I booked the walkthrough, I would do the following once I booked it....

Within minutes of booking it:

1) I'm on Google Earth looking at the size of their space from space. I'm looking at the layout. I'm looking for shrubs or plants next to the property (cause of bugs...and spiders). I'm looking at parking to see how many could be working in there, and I'm looking at parking for our team (we're out of DC where parking is rough). I'm looking on Google Maps to see what neighbors they have we can clean. I'll plan to go door to door for them.

2) I'm googling the address to pull up the LoopNet listing to grab the sqft. I'm looking at the property manager. I'm looking at lease rates. I'm looking for floor plans if available.

3) I'm on the dental clinic's website and social media. I'm looking at any cleaning challenges in there. I'm looking at their vents in their pictures (dirty vents = dust issues). I'm looking at the floor types (likely LVP). 

4) I'm using one of my medical proposal templates to put together a rough proposal just to save time. I don't give them a proposal or a price in my walkthrough.

On the day of the walkthrough...

1) I show up 5 minutes early dressed in slacks and a biz button down shirt with our logo embroidered on it (I'm a guy) and I'm carrying only my notebook w/ biz cards and maybe a brochure.

2) I exchange pleasantries for 2-5 minutes.

3) I ask them to show me around.

4) While we're walking around I ask a dozen questions. The first one below I always ask first. Half of my questions are around their pain points. The other half are around logistics that impact my time and price in their space.

a) How did you find us? (assuming I don't know)
b) What do you like best about the cleaning service you have here now?
c) What do you like least about the cleaning service you have here now?
d) If we could change one thing about the cleaning today, what would that one thing be?
e) How many days per week would you like us cleaning in here? If they make a recommendation that doesn't make sense, I'll pushback (ie a 5000 sqft should be cleaned 2-3X/week at a minimum.
f) If the space is clean and spotless, I point that out too. "This space looks clean. Why do you want to change?"
g) I see in your restroom here that you have toilet paper, paper towels, hand soap, and liners. Do you need us to provide any of these items?
h) They will give out keywords and I listen for them. For example, if they say dust 3 times, I'll stop them and bluntly say, "This is the third time you mentioned dust. This sounds very important to you. Do I have that right?" It means it's a hot button and responding like that shows you're actively listening. It's like a Jedi mind trick.
i) What time in the evening can we begin cleaning in here?
j) How soon would you want us to start cleaning?
k) We provide our own supplies and equipment (ie a vacuum). Would you happen to have a closet or space that we can store these items?
l) Would you happen to have any lockup procedures for us if we're selected, like alarms?
m) You have X-ray, patient trays, patient chairs, labs areas, etc. here, Do you need us to clean these areas? (99% no, you don't).

5) As I walkthrough I do chicken scratch and I also make a rough floor plan using sized squares on my paper. I'll also count fixtures in the restrooms. I only put on my notes what's different about this space compared to other locations (ie water fountain, elevator, etc.).

6) Your 5000 sqft space should take 10-12 minutes to walkthrough at best. I cram in as many of these questions as I can in that short period of time. At the end of the walkthrough (and I time it as best as I can), I will then summarize what they told me in 2 minutes or less. "If I get this right, we're cleaning here 2X per week on Tuesday and Saturday, and we can begin after 6pm. What's important to you is X, Y, and Z and blah, blah, blah, etc. 

7) I then give my 30 second elevator pitch. I include in that 3 things that make us different about dental practice cleaning than 99% of our competitors.

8 ) I finally give them next steps and that includes confirming their email so I can send a proposal. 

That's it.

text:
I have a question for all you "green cleaners" out there. I'm currently in the planning stages of building Grassroots Cleaning , which will be a green cleaning business, and the plan is to scale over time. (As fast as possible but also not too fast. Slow and steady wins the race as they say). My first goal is to hire 10 cleaners in the first year. But I digress...

I have all of my products picked out but one. DISINFECTANT!

I'm having such a hard time because I LOVE my Odoban because it's:
- ph neutral
- a hospital grade disinfectant
- cost effective

âœ¨ï¸ I love all these "features" because it allows new employees with little training to have a "when in doubt" product besides dishsoap and even though hospital grade isn't necessary all the time, I like having the option. It's great for preventing mold, cleaning toilets, etc.

I really can't find anything that compares. "Homemade" options like hydrogen peroxide are too expensive for a company looking to scale. Vinegar and Alcohol can damage surfaces. Citric acid can damage surfaces. Hypochlorous acid is also not cost-effective, and I've looked into Force of Nature, RMR, Clean Republic, and some other brands also.. But none are concentrated and again just not cost-effective. Just not realisitc for a company who's going to be cleaning (hopefully) a couple dozen houses a week.

I've considered ordering HCOL (Hypocholrus acid) tablets and keeping them handy, then also buying Odoban and just being transparent with clients and giving them the option... but other than that I'm not sure what else my options could be. I've been Googling and ChatGPT-ing for days! Lol. 

Any suggestions?

topComments.text: Are you planning on doing any commercial cleaning? I can tell you ever since Covid. My clients probably 95% of them or more do not care about green clean and this is just my suggestion. Take it with a grain of salt but I would offer a green clean, You can even up charge a little bit to use that product line, but I would definitely not eliminate all of the other cleaners especially if youâ€™re doing commercial.  If I owned a nightclub or a daycare where viruses were going around I would want the heavy duty stuff if youâ€™re cleaning a restaurant after hours in the urinals are disgusting if I owned the place, I wouldnâ€™t want someone coming in and spraying plant-based essential oils at the urinal.  Again just wanted to give you a different perspective because the truth is most people could care less they want a good clean and good sanitizing. iâ€™m in the process of creating a product line right now which Iâ€™m gonna sell on Shopify, Amazon TikTok shop and itâ€™s going to be about 95% plant based but Iâ€™m also putting in the stuff we need in a small amount. ï¿¼ I actually had a friend who branded her business as fully green clean all natural products. I talked her out of it and she was so happy that I did. With that being said, you can always offer it to those few people that are saying thatâ€™s all they want.

Feel free to message me so we can discuss. I use a product that contains live probiotics which is actually better than a disinfectant. It's commercial grade. I have to buy 4 gallons at a time and mix our own spray bottles but it's super economical.

text:
Hi guys, I have a question. I have a whole family that purchased $2000 worth of gift cards around Christmas time and unfortunately every single person that has been gifted part of that gift card money from that family has been a complete headache. It has been impossible to please them and I have never had more rude customers since having this business. My question is one of them has a $500 gift card that they are using for todayâ€™s service. She told me she had a gift card and we knew that she was going to use that but when arriving at The clean today, she told me she was going to use her sisterâ€™s gift card that couldnâ€™t use it so sheâ€™s asking to use some of that other gift card for the balance, which wouldâ€™ve been $100 cash 

Then sheâ€™s expecting that the other $400 from that gift card will get used by someone else in her family. I initially told her it would have been nice to know. She had two gift cards to begin with so that we could have coordinated that and she snapped and got really upset. I guess my question is is this comment to use a second gift card to cover the balance and then expect the remaining balance on that gift card to be tossed around to another house ?? ï¿¼ or should I say that each gift card is for one household what would you do ï¿¼ï¿¼ï¿¼ï¿¼

topComments.text: Unfortunately, this is one of those things that need to be specified ahead of time. You are going to have to stick to whatever terms you put out there initially. If you don't have it posted somewhere (website, socials) or haven't verbally expressed to them that more than one gift card can't be used per household, they will likely give you a hard time about that. Moving forward, you can at any time update policies - you live and learn and make adjustments. I would just be careful with these people if you already know they are finicky. Personally, I would just let them do it if you have not expressed to them previously that they can't or don't have it posted somewhere. I say that only because I would much rather deal with it even if I didn't want to then risk a bad review if something was not communicated up front.

Truthfully, I wouldâ€™ve been annoyed with you also. That that was nice of the family to spend that much money with your company. They will eat through it quickly. Just smile kill them with kindness and whatever they run through them. I just wouldnâ€™t do gift cards again, anytime that I have ever done Gift cards or here in New Jersey. The schools do something called tricky trays where you can donate I did it a bunch in the beginning 100% of the time when I would do a giveaway and I would do just a three or four hour clean we would have these people acting like they won the entire lottery and we were gonna give them a full home makeover it was hilarious. I would get into it with them on the phone saying theyâ€™re gonna need more people if we are doing the refrigerator the inside of the oven and Iâ€™m letting them know weâ€™re not gonna have time for that with one girl for three or four hours. This is a mini clean that I donated and then theyâ€™re trying to tell me thatâ€™s not what I won lol so I donâ€™t do those anymore. 
But if they have already paid even if itâ€™s the sisterâ€™s gift card, I would let her use it. I donâ€™t think about it. She will be gone soon.

text: So I have my first commercial cleaning walk through estimate this weekend and I have no idea what to expect or how to price it ha! Does anyone have any tips for me? They have their own zamboni for floors andv3 bathrooms. TIA!

topComments.text: Take videos and photos of as much as you can to help you remember what you saw and to use later if you arenâ€™t the one to clean there.

Show up. 

Ask over a dozen questions. Half of mine are designed to flush out pain points (what's their biggest struggle with cleaning and why did they pick up the phone to call to begin with). And the other half are designed to solicit answers to my logistical questions (ie frequency, scope of work requests, floor scrubber use, window of time to clean, etc).

I walkthrough while asking questions. At the end I summarize what they told me in 2 minutes or less. Then I give a 30 sec elevator pitch. Finally I give my next steps (ie I'll send you over a proposal...and I confirm their email). Then I go out for coffee and crunch numbers while the info is fresh in my mind.

I never ever never give a price in a walkthrough. Don't sweat a price just yet.

Don't say "Zamboni" to them for sure. Call it a floor scrubber. 

If the have a floor scrubber that you sit on, like a Tennant T7, they have to have a large floor area to make it worthwhile. Those machines can run over $20K. So congrats on the opportunity. 

Walkthrough and soak it all in. Take a ton of notes. Then post back.

text:
Hey fellow maid service owners!

As you probably know, California rolled out a big change in 2019 regarding how we classify independent contractors versus employees â€“ it's often called the ABC test. Based on Prong B of that test, a worker is considered an employee if they're doing work that's part of our main business. For us, that means cleaning technicians would likely have to be classified as employees, since, well, cleaning is our core service!

So, I'm curious:

Has anyone found a way to legally keep working with independent contractors for cleaning services, even with the ABC test? If so, how exactly did you pull that off legally?

And for those of you who have employees, is it okay to have them provide their own cleaning supplies?

Any advice or experiences would be super helpful! Thanks!

topComments.text: I'm in California. S.B.5 (the gig worker law that mainly affected rideshare companies and delivery drivers) ended the option to have independent contractors unless they are truly independent and have their own clients. Plus, the IC sets price and can accept or reject an invitation to a job. No uniforms from your business or they'll be classified as an employee. You can have absolutely no direction in when they work, how they do it, or what they use. It does have a carve out for domestic referral agencies, but the ICs need to truly be ICs. Nobody wants to be audited by the State. They have four different agencies that can harass you. That's what I'm currently working on.

Yes, I have and always will only be independent contractors. It depends on your state and if by chance you can make friends with your local IRS agent and go over some things with them, print out the rules and just make sure that you kind of bend here in there like for me, for example I am in New Jersey. My IRS agent told me about those ABC things so I just bend a little like if for example, your cleaners have a regular schedule every week and they are full-time that is supposed to be considered W-2 so what I do to get around that is every Thursday I ask everybody if they can please give me their schedule for the upcoming week. I always have two or three girls that need to take a certain day off so then I will rearrange the schedule that way I can turn back around until the IRS look at this. I am a website based business and I have to sub out cleaners to fulfill the service. Promise I can never have a set schedule because we donâ€™t know exactly what weâ€™re doing the schedules always changing so I can prove them wrong on everything basically but itâ€™s not that serious. The other thing is youâ€™re not supposed to give them a uniform but for me, I can show that we use the uniform for social media promoting for my website based cleaning company And if the girls wear it so that we can do filming but Iâ€™m not a typical cleaning business basically I can show a bunch of ways that Iâ€™m not a typical cleaning business I make that happen..

text: Do you use checklists for every home where the cleaner has to initial per task ?

topComments.text:
Iâ€™m honestly torn when it comes to checklists. I see the value of using them for new techs as theyâ€™re learning and still building their routines, but requiring every tech to use them consistentlyâ€”or leaving them behind at every homeâ€”feels unnecessary in some cases.

When I think back to my time as a cleaning tech, if my boss had required me to use a checklist, I know Iâ€™d have just checked everything off automatically without much thought, simply because I was confident in my routine. Sure, I missed things from time to time, but I donâ€™t think a checklist would have changed thatâ€”it wouldnâ€™t have added value for me once I knew the job.

Now, if your company does more custom cleaningâ€”where tasks vary from home to homeâ€”then I can definitely see checklists being more beneficial. Having a list in those cases would help ensure nothing gets overlooked when every house has a different set of tasks.

So for me, it really depends on the type of service model: standard vs. highly customized.

I was using one internally for staff to check, but I'm now introducing them to leave behind at each clean to create more accountability between the cleaner and the client. I also feel its good for the client to see that we are working to a checklist as we charge more, so its an additional value to the service.

My gut reaction is **no**, because the flat monthly rate already is low.. text:
Has anyone dealt with their spouse or partner interfering in their cleaning business?

Hereâ€™s a bit of background: Iâ€™ve been cleaning solo for over 20 years. For most of that time, I only had a few regular clients and made around $400â€“$500/week. I kept expenses low, sometimes even using client supplies, and Iâ€™d deposit everything into our joint account. It worked fine for that season of lifeâ€”my focus was raising our kids and just bringing in a little extra.

Now the kids are grown, Iâ€™m 50, and my business has grown a lot. Iâ€™m bringing in $900â€“$1,000/week in revenue, but Iâ€™m also burning out. I want to shift from being the cleaner to being the business ownerâ€”build a team, scale properly, and separate my business finances from personal ones.

Hereâ€™s the challenge: My husband is used to the old setupâ€”low overhead, all income flowing into the joint account, and no real distinction between personal and business money. He says he supports me hiring help and growing the business, but when it comes to spending money to make that happen, he gets resistant. I think heâ€™s struggling with the idea that more revenue doesnâ€™t mean more available money right away. Also giving up control of what my income is being spent on. 

Has anyone else navigated this kind of transition with a partner who wasnâ€™t quite on board financially or mentally?
 â€¢ Did you involve your spouse in budget or business planning to help them understand?
 â€¢ What helped shift their mindset so they could see the big picture?

Any advice or shared experiences would be so appreciated!

topComments.text:
When I started, all my profits were going into my personal account. That only lasted a few months. My partner and I had a conversation that income would change when I get legit and I wanted to be legit sooner rather than later.

Fast forward a few months and I have a business account set up and payroll. I pay myself out $16 an hour, that way I can benefit from my personal tax breaks like the earned income credit and child tax credit. I remind my family that Iâ€™m not making the whole job in my personal account but we can benefit from the business in other ways like tax breaks. I also use my business account to cover gas expenses which saves how much I spend on my personal account.

Remind him that supplies are still a low cost if you are pricing your jobs accordingly and you
Wonâ€™t be paying for them personally, that comes from the business account.

Hi Anonymous,  So awesome you've made the decision to shift into being the owner rather than the cleaner.  Can I suggest you get a copy of Profit First and set up multiple bank accounts as per that system if it grabs you as being the right structure moving forward (I implemented it six months ago and it's been fabulous and rewarding and helped me to see my business far more clearly).  It might also help hubby to see the big picture, why it's necessary for things to be changing financially, where the money will be going and what it will be used for, and what the financial benefits will be.   Perhaps it's also time to clearly define or redefine what his role will be in the business, if at all, now that you're stepping up into this new chapter.  Change can bring up a lot of fear (hence the resistance), so he may need more clarity, reassurance, or just time to get used to it.  Sounds like a great opportunity to hone your conflict resolution skills, which you will definitely need as business expands ðŸ™‚  Hope this helps in some way ðŸ™‚

text:
Hello All - I've had my business for almost 5 years.  We're at $50k a month, 13 staff, 165 routines.  We have field processes set in writing and need to develop policies and procedures for the admin and sales functions.  We also need to figure out how to expand operations.  

I like to think about my business as having been developed in Phases.  Phase 1 - I learned how to clean houses. I had a few helpers, and that lasted a year or so.  In Phase 2 - I learned how to find, train, and retain (ish) real employees, and how to scale up to serving clients I never even meet.  I brought on a sales person and a field "manager" of sorts, who helps me train and covers for folks when they call off or quit without notice.  Our sales guy can't take any more leads and my field assistant is at capacity.  It's time to go to Phase 3.

Phase 3 is where the real business starts to come into existence.  Phase 3 is where I take off some of these hats and give them to people with the capacity to manage those functions for me.

I am currently reading Traction, by Gino Wickman for ideas on how to get to the next level, but I feel like it's maybe written more for Phase 4 (taking that real company into real market dominance).

So, I am looking for a group on Facebook of similarly-positioned cleaning companies to network with and learn from, resources to explore and maybe some "atta girl" type support from folks who've made it to and through Phase 3.  TIA :)

topComments.text:
Not sure if this'll help but here's how I've approached building and scaling my cleaning biz to run 90-95% without me and have people running the show.

Btw, I've been in the cleaning industry for 1 year and we're at approx $20k/month. Outside of cleaning, I have a few other companies (including coaching, marketing, author) that makes multiple 7-figs a year.

Everyone says to hire more people, create SOPS, use AI or automation... and those are true but most people do this in the wrong order.

Hiring someone new should be the last thing you do... not the first.

The first (and most important) thing you should do is familiarize yourself with all of the important KPIs that's important for your business (CPL, CAC, LTV, Gross & Net Profit %, etc). These will help you establish a baseline so that if your company starts to be ran by other people, you know the metrics to look at to see if you're still within your range.

I have a scorecard template on Google I can share that takes these... just ask and I can send (idk if I can put links here).

Then, once you have that together, then I have this thing that I do with all of my businesses which is something with the acronym of SEAD (systemize, eliminate, automate, then delegate).

So in that order, I start by systemizing HOW each of my business functions needs to work (marketing, fulfillment, operations, hiring, etc)... I essentially decide and define "this is how we do things" which will be helpful for the next person who is overseeing it.

More could be said there but that's the high level of it.

Then, I go through a stage of elimination where I try to simplify the business function as much as possible. Our mktg process, our fulfillment, our hiring... what can I remove from the process without breaking it.

Then, I take that same biz function and think about all of the parts of it that I can either automate or have AI aide me in. Think of things like automatically following up with leads after x days or follow up w/ past customers after 3 months for re-clean.

Then, finally once I go through all of that, I find team members (my team is based in Colombia) that runs the rest of the process. I go through this SEAD thing with all of my businesses functions so that by the time I've delegated the work, i'm completely hands off.

This is a very very high level breakdown but hope it helps you think about the order to approach this next phase with... especially as you start wanting to bring more people to help you work ON the business and not just IN it.

text:
So I have a situation..
Full time employee was showing she clocked in late yesterday (by 15 mins). Didnt message me or manager to let us know and when i addressed it, she took the day to get back to me.  She called me and said she was late because she ran home to get her dog since the client she was cleaning for had asked for a play date with her dog. This employee does dog walking on the side and a lot of clients like her for this reason because sheâ€™s very great with dogs. I was very frustrated especially since I had asked this client if employee was late since employee took so long to get back to me and client said no. We have had this client since day one and I felt very irritated about the whole situation but I already addressed to both client and employee why thatâ€™s not allowed. We cannot mix business with personal and I explained why and told employee it canâ€™t happen again. Both said they understood and were very positive about it. Iâ€™m just wondering if I am covering all my bases good enough? Am I missing something? Should I have a written warning? Should I have employee sign something? Am I overreacting? What would you do?

topComments.text: To all of the above saying it's not an issue. If you allow one employee to do whatever she wants, like bring her dog on company time, which is not something that is part of work, then you risk every employee do whatever they want. Also even though 15 minutes isn't a huge deal, she should have informed you she was going to be late and reason why,  just like you would have to in any other job. Bringing her dog to your client's home on company time is a liability to you. It is the same as bringing a kid to your clients home. She needs to stick to her job duties in a professional way. You did the right thing! Maybe you need to have a meeting with all your employees and go over your policies.

Oh my goodness, I think I may have written it in a way that was not expressing why I was frustrated clearly
I think Iâ€™m more appalled that everyone here is overlooking the fact that our employee went to go get her dog and bring it over to a clientâ€™s house when she was supposed to be cleaning and at work and failed to tell us 
She is mixing personal with Business. I donâ€™t understand why this is OK in everyoneâ€™s eyes but I guess we are the minority in this industry - sheesh!ï¿¼

text:
ðŸš¨ Calling all experienced cleaners & cleaning business owners! 
My friend and I just launched our new cleaning company **Abode and Beyond Knox** here in Tennessee, and weâ€™re building our toolkit and training process the *right* way from the start. ðŸ’ªâœ¨

We could really use your wisdom on a few key things:

ðŸ§¼ **Best Cleaning Products:**
Weâ€™re looking for top go-to products that are:
* Effective on most surfaces
* Gentle or no scent (great for sensitive clients!)
* Safe and professional looking

ðŸŽ¥ **Training Videos or Systems:**
Do you have a favorite video, channel, or method you use to train new staff the same way every time? We want to build consistency and quality across the board.

ðŸ§¹ **Favorite Vacuums for Pros:**
We need vacuums that are:
* Durable and reliable
* Work great on both carpet & hard floors
* Easy to clean and maintain for a small team

Drop your go-to tools and tips below! ðŸ§½ðŸ§¼ Your insights could really help usâ€”and othersâ€”get started on the right foot. Thank you in advance! ðŸ™Œ

topComments.text:
Call your local chemical distributor.  They will come out and talk to you about their chemical lines.  You want a neutral cleaner that has a neutral Ph so it will be safe on all surfaces. This will also be your cheapest way to go. Most of the time you will buy the chemical concentrate and then you will dilute yourself so each gallon will cost you well under $1.00.

We use the vanisher canister vacuums from Vacland. They are powerful and not very expensive.  They sell all the replacement parts, so when something breaks you can just fix the broken part.

I like cannister vacuums, maneuvering,  suction, but longevity sucks of dyson total clean.
Shark navigator for carpets but upright vacuum.

Top to bottom cleaning obviously,  making sure things are out of your way so no trip hazards..

I like warm soap water on wood tables so no scrubbing required (can strip)
Lock the door behind you when entering a clients house, for protection. 
Detail brushes around sink and faucets, drains.

I like barkeepers friend on stainless and ranges,  the liquid for the range, powder for the sinks.

I have been using dawn dishsoap, vinegar and water for showers and bathrooms for soap scum but lately changed to a canadian brand myni for all my cleaning products.

text:
Regarding preparing to sell a cleaning bizâ€¦ 

I know itâ€™s important to have client contracts in place. However, when you define â€œcontractsâ€, does this mean signed contracts that last a specific amount of time and have an expiration date, or just simple written agreements for recurring cleanings (until the client cancels)?

If I do not have binding agreements for a certain amount of time with my clients, do I only have the option to sell a â€œclient listâ€?ï¿¼

topComments.text:
I've bought and I've sold. Buyers want to know that you have an agreement in place vs. something verbal or something in text. You don't have to lock your clients into a contract term. We have annual contracts and they can cancel at any time. They just want to know that the service offering is locked in, that there won't be any scope creep, and that there is a signed agreement on the price and the payment terms. I personally don't see why cleaning business owners don't do contracts. I will not buy any book of business or company if there is no signed contract. 

Aside from that, the buyer wants to buy a business and not a job. Make sure you're not the one cleaning. I also look at the length of history with each client and the distribution of income with each client. Finally, I really look at the P&L, bank balances/cash flow statements, and the balance sheet.

whats more important are: can your business operate without you ? Do you have SYSTEMS in place for your staff and procedures etc? If all you have is a client list and YOUR THE ONE CLEANING, then correct, you can't sell "business" because what you have is a self employment job. I'm not an expert thats just what I know to be the basics. You'll need profit and loss statements, balance sheet, etc. to show investors or brokers. maybe talk to a broker and see what their advice is. goodluck!!

text:
I own a house cleaning company, and I'm reevaluating my training program, so I would appreciate some input. 
 

For folks with employees, after your initial two-week or so training period, what kind of ongoing training or retraining do you provide for your staff?* *

topComments.text: I just downloaded a training system from Stephanie Pipkin of Serene Clean.

After initial training, we pair new cleaners with a team lead for hands-on supportâ€”typically for 1â€“2 weeks, though it depends on how quickly they catch on. Once they're working solo, our quality check manager visits at the end of their cleanings to review their work, point out anything they may have missed, and teach them how to double-check their own work moving forward.

Most of the time, missed details aren't due to lazinessâ€”they're just not slowing down to double-check. Thatâ€™s something we drill in during training and continue to reinforce! We also do ongoing quality checks for anyone with concerns and mix in random spot-checks to keep standards high across the board.

text: How can i take this fly screen out without breaking it?

text:
Hi everyone!
Iâ€™ve recently started offering independent cleaning services and Iâ€™m looking for effective ways to get the word out. If youâ€™ve had success promoting a small service business, Iâ€™d love your adviceâ€”what platforms, apps, or marketing strategies worked best for you?
Thanks so much in advance for any tips!

Has anyone teamed up with Real Estate agents or any other industry professionals that give welcome/thank you baskets to their clients. Would love to know what kind of offers y'all include ($100/off first clean, your usual promos, gift cards, etc).

topComments.text: Teaming up with Real Estate agents can be super beneficial, but not in a "We want to clean for your clients" sort of way. Agents live and die on referrals, so propose a referral partnership with them. This is language they understand. They know that you will likely be one of the first people to know when one of your clients is thinking about selling. When you recommend them, and then they know anyone (clients, hairdresser, nail tech, parents at school, etc) who inquires about cleaning, they will refer you. These can be very good partnerships. Agents are usually well-known in the community and trusted as a reliable resource for many types of home services. You don't really need to incentivize it. They know the value of referrals, but you could say that for their clients, you'd do a discount of some sort, but it's not just about them referring you to their clients. If you make a good impression and refer them, they will refer you to their entire network, which goes well beyond just their clients.
I have not but I like this idea, especially since I know quite a few agents personally who I could offer this to.

text: You guys require first time clients to be there for any portion of the first time clean? We seem to be getting a lot of new clients who arenâ€™t there to do a walk-through to begin with and arenâ€™t there for a walk-through at the end. ï¿¼

It also gets that relationship build that is all important...but you cant see the dirt on videos lol

We like it when the client is not there. They get in your way and ask for more than they ordered. They will call if there is an issue which there should not be if you have a detailed process that is consistently utilized

text:
I'm newly on a hourly rate model after it wasn't really working on flat rate model. Still a newer business, I could really use some input and ideas from others that are charging by the hour! 

We charge $47/labor hour for maintenance/regular cleaning. 

Deep cleaning is $55/ labor hour.  We have a 3 hour minimum booking. 

Now, what about when you have a Independent Contractor that does excellent work and works very fast? She has over 10 years of experience, and  is often finished before the 3 hour minimum on a smaller /medium sized homes.       

If you have a 3 hour minimum, but it only takes your cleaners 2 hours to clean a home, do you still charge them 3 hours? Or do you allow the homeowner to give your cleaner extra tasks to do to meet those 3 hours ? 

I recently had a client have us Clean her Baseboards and Exterior Kitchen Cabinets to meet the 3 hour minimum that she paid for. However, those are 'Deep Clean' tasks.     

How do we differentiate when a customer books an hourly maintenance service, then expect deep cleaning tasks to be done during this time because they're paying for hourly ?  Or ... do you just charge one flat hourly rate, whether its a deep clean or regular clean, it's the same hourly rate?

topComments.text: Hi there, I can answer this for you. I only do 1099 subcontractors and I have been that way with five different locations over the last 20 years. There will definitely be people that say you have to make everybody a W-2 employee if youâ€™re doing certain things, but that is not the case if you are running an online Cleaning business and then youâ€™re hiring people to fulfill a service promise for your online business. There are a couple certain things that you cannot do you do need to stay in regulation. I highly recommend speaking with your local IRS agent as well as either emailing back-and-forth or doing a phone call with The labor and wages departments of your state. I have both of those people for me that Iâ€™m in contact with the only thing that they said Iâ€™m not really supposed to do is make the girls wear uniforms so I just let them wear all black because we do need to stay within branding because Iâ€™m an â€œonline businessâ€ I have them look very branded for social media promotional things so my business does not fall into the typical cleaning company that needs W-2 so you need to make some changes. Anyways, moving along from that I charge clients hourly and I pay my cleaners hourly we also have a three hour minimum because I offered the girls a 6 to 8 hour workday. I do not pay for drive time and I do not pay for the break but they do get four dollars per gas per house so at the end of the week if they did 10 cleans, they get $40 in gas I would not want to do the deep cleaning rate and regular cleaning rate different because it would confuse me it would confuse the client there would be weird gray area where theyâ€™re trying to argue with you that it wasnâ€™t that deep of a clean it should only be a regular so if I were you, I would switch that. Keep it easy straight across the board. The thing is if they want to add in deep cleaning duties itâ€™s gonna take more time. So you can even add another cleaner on and charge them that way, which is what I would do with my company anything over the two girls for three hours in the home which is the most popular clean I offer I give one free hour, so Iâ€™m only 41.50 a man first time clean is always full price and then I encourage them to get on a regular schedule that we stay extremely busy but I can offer them this day and time if that would work for them and they do get the one hour for free going forward almost everybody that has first service with us will pop on the schedule which for me thatâ€™s always my goal. I wanna keep it at 10 cleaners full of regulars to where Iâ€™m only basically staying on call with everybody for changes. I do very little work now throughout the week. I have very low overhead and I love my set up. I donâ€™t need office managers. I donâ€™t need an office even though I have one for my other business and I kind of consider it for the cleaning business for Mail purposes, but I personally am very into not having 40 cleaners five managers because I feel like at the end of the day After paying everybody out and dealing with all that stress I would end up making the same amount that I am now I make for myself about $12-$14,000 a month. ï¿¼ Sorry very long. Talk to text. Hope some of that information can help. Iâ€™m very open book if you would like to know anything else.
I charge $60/hr/cleaner regardless of what they want cleaned. Two hour minimum.

text:
Hi! We had a working interview work for a day for us. He didnâ€™t work out in the end and is now coming after us. He wrote us our first bad review in 5 years and said we treat our employees bad. He said because we didnâ€™t give him a lunch or compensate his travel time. We give our EMPLOYEES, gas bonuses for travel but we donâ€™t pay them for in between clients houses. 
Heâ€™s threatening to report us to the BBB and write more bad reviews. When he worked the working interview, it wasnâ€™t a full day either. It was maybe 5 hours max. What are our options here and how would you handle this??

topComments.text:
It is a direct violation of Google policy for current or former employees to leave reviews.   Click the three vertical dots next to the review to request removal where the option is related to that offense.

Don't reply to the review.  It makes it harder to remove.  And that goes for any review that violates Google policy.  Never reply to them, just submit the request for removal.

**Response to Review:**

We're sorry to hear you felt your experience didn't meet your expectations. Weâ€™d like to clarify that what you participated in was a *working interview*â€”a common industry practice which gives both parties a chance to determine fit before any formal employment offer is made. 

The working interview was under 5 hours, and as it is not formal employment, our employee benefits and travel bonuses do not apply. Our company policy â€” which has kept us in good standing with our team for over 5 years â€” includes fair compensation, gas bonuses for employees, and respectful treatment of our staff.

Weâ€™re proud of our team culture and value feedback, but we believe this review does not accurately reflect our business practices or the positive environment we work hard to maintain. We wish you the best in your future opportunities.

text: I am just starting out and need help with marketing to Airbnb owners! How do you find them and start?

topComments.text: We only service Airbnbs too and we use MarketplaceSTR! Quite a few leads come from it!

You starting a new service added to an existing cleaning business or literally just starting a cleaning business that focuses exclusively on short-term rental cleaning? 

If the latter, I would recommend reconsidering that strategy for two critical reasons.

#1.  You can barely generate reviews because it's the same owner all the time, you have no connection to all the many customers that rent the unit out.  Reviews are critical for showing up higher in search and being chosen once found.

This will force you to consistently rely on direct selling and direct advertising which is harder to scale, more challenging and comes with higher customer acquisition costs.

#2. If another covid happens (or anything else that impacts travel to the same degree) you'll be out of business. I would not recommend subjecting yourself to that kind of risk exposure.

If adding short-term rental cleaning to an existing business, there are some inbound marketing strategies and depending on city, there may be publicly available records of licensed addresses.  From there you can do bulk mail.

text: What is the best lead generation for cleaning business.?

topComments.text:
Depends on the business.  It won't be the same for each business. In fact it can vary wildly.

Startup vs. Established brand

Geography

Target avatar

Commercial vs. Residential vs. Short-term rental cleaning

Time capital vs. Money capital (if you're bootstrapping and have time but no budget, then it's going to have to be direct selling / networking, etc.  If you have money capital then direct advertising and inbound marketing... or potentially a combination of the two if you have both time and money).
Quick way to get leads is LSA

text: Hey everyone. Does anyone clean wedding venues? I live in a role area and there are several barns that have been turned into venues. Does anyone have suggestions on pricing? Do you do hourly rate? Do you go by a checklist?

topComments.text: I quoted one once. Remember with wedding venues, you may have to clean at the crack of dawn on Sat and Sun mornings to meet their turnaround. Worse, in our case, many other cultures have very early morning ceremonies, so you may end up cleaning in the middle of the nightâ€¦after an evening wedding but before the morning wedding. Ugh.

We have done one that was in a converted barn.  We did an hourly rate. Included the large reception area with wiping the tables and floors being cleaned as well as a 2 stall and 1 stall bathroom and small bride and groom suites surfaces and floors. 3 hours was the goal. The owner had photos for us of what each area should look like when finished for where things went. 

Definitely have a checklist and find out what you are responsible for especially if the renters donâ€™t do anything that may be required of them. 

Even if the renters are supposed to have cleaned up/removed items they may not.

text: Happy Friday! Question. We provide technicians with compensation for time spent driving between houses, utilizing Google estimated time. However, road construction during spring and summer is causing route delays. One technician is requesting compensation for the additional time spent driving between houses. Is this a legitimate claim for reimbursement? I would like to know other's opinions. .  TIA

topComments.text: Yes. Construction is completely out of drivers control and takes more time and fuel.

We use a time tracking app that lets them clock in for travel time, so if theyâ€™re gonna take a 30 minute break they clock out and then they clocked back in for travel when theyâ€™re back on the clock. Makes it super easy to track their time.

So to answer your question, yes you are responsible for compensating them for travel time even if they get stuck in construction traffic. If you do decide to use a time tracking app, I recommend using one that has GPS location.   That helps to ensure they are clocking in and clocking out at the right places.

Would anyone be willing to share the list of questions you ask your new clients to help you refine your estimates over the phone? This is what I currently have:
* What type of cleaning are you looking to get quoted for?
* Do you currently reside in the home?

* Have you recently had any renovations or construction done in the last 2 months. Have you had a cleaning done then?
* How many bedrooms?
* How many offices?
* How many bathrooms?
* Include inside of the oven?
* Include inside of refrigerator?
* Include outside of the cabinets?
* Include top of the cabinets?
* Do you have any pets?
* Do you have a finished basement that youâ€™d like to include?
* Have you had your home professionally cleaned before? If yes, how long ago?

topComments.text:
Name, number, email, address, # of bedrooms & bathrooms, sq. footage, pets, type of cleaning needed, how often, when was the last time it was professionally cleaned.

ï¿¼ I do not ask if they want certain things cleaned. We have our own checklists which I provide of what is included in that type of cleaning. The interior of appliances are an add-on for us except for a move in/ move out(they are included).

I will strictly never give a potential client a quote over the phone if they insist I will give them a very varied price range so that they want the quote in person I emphasize on the fact that not only do we not want to under charge for our work but we also donâ€™t want to over charge and the fairest way to give a price is by an at home assessment which I offer for free. 

I do this because you never know what you may find when you get there. 
And also there are times when I have even done a in person assessment and estimate the time to be completely different because once you start to move things it ends up taking longer basically. Luckily this doesnâ€™t happen a lot but my point is that I couldnâ€™t imagine guessing a price based on some questions and gambling with my profits and loss.

text: where does everyone post there Terms & Conditions so the client can agree to them? and how do you let the clients see them? thank you!

topComments.text:
we include them in our cost proposal and also as a reminder on their first appointment confirmation.  We then attach a copy of the cost proposal to every invoice. We don't have contracts that clients sign... these are simply "meeting of the mind" type "gentlemen" agreements...  our t & c look like this:  

IMPORTANT INFORMATION - PLEASE READ - Considerations for Routine and Deep Cleaning:

ïƒ˜ Preparations: Please make your home ready for cleaning by putting dishes, toiletries, laundry, and clutter away, if possible. Also, consider picking up towels, bathmats, and washable throw rugs and placing them in the laundry as doing this will lead to a cleaner experience, overall.

We will do what we can if you do not have time to prepare your home for cleaning but note that we may not be able to complete everything on our task list if we need to spend time on these preparatory tasks. Also - if there is something in your home that is unreplaceable - either put it away in a space we do not clean or notify your cleaner to take extra care around that specific item. 412 Clean Teams is both careful and fully insured, but we know that some items' sentimental value is simply unreplaceable.

ïƒ˜ Pets: Most of our clients have pets, and we love cleaning alongside them. It is very important to us that your pets remain safe while we clean. However, as we are focused on cleaning your home, we expect our clients to ensure their petsâ€™ safety. It is our policy to clean with the exit doors closed to help prevent your petâ€™s escape, but we do need to enter and exit, so if your pet is a flight risk, please secure them in a safe location while we clean. Additionally, while we do not require our clients to kennel their dogs, we do require pets to be sequestered if they pose any risk to our team members or your property while we clean. 

ïƒ˜ Making Space: While our Cleaning Technician is working, please minimize your use of the rooms we are working in. Please also limit your use of the stove before we clean it to make sure it is cool to the touch.

ïƒ˜ Payment: 412 Clean Teams uses Square, a third-party, secure, on-line credit and debit card processing service. Upon scheduling your cleaning service, an invoice will be created and emailed to the email address listed above. A link for on-line digital payments will be present in the message, and some services require a 50% deposit. Any issues with service affecting payment should be directed to us via telephone, text, or email using the contact information provided herein. 

ïƒ˜ Tips: Tips for your House Cleaner are not expected but are always appreciated.  The best way to tip your cleaner is with cash, given directly to your cleaner. You may, of course, simply add the tip in your regular payment for services, just know that taxes and fees will apply, and the cleaner will receive your tip less these fees in their regular paycheck.

ïƒ˜ Cancellations - If you need to cancel less than 48 hours before your scheduled cleaning, a 50% late cancellation fee will apply.  This allows us to honor our promises to our staff and pay them for the time they have set aside to clean your home. We are perfectly comfortable cleaning in your absence and are prepared to mask up and clean if you or one of your household members is ill. (In that case, we would only ask that the ill person in your home sequesters themselves and wears a mask should they need to move about while we are cleaning.)  If your circumstances are such that you cannot provide for the above cancellation consideration, please give us a call.  

LOCK OUT: Also note: if we cannot gain entry to your home when we arrive, we expect payment in full, regardless of whether we clean.  We send text messages prior to our arrival and will attempt to contact you if we cannot get in.  We will also wait ten minutes from your scheduled appointment before leaving.

Additional Services, Agreements, and Feedback:

ïƒ˜ Additional Services - please refer to the above list of tasks we will execute at every cleaning. If you have additional rooms to clean or tasks that you would like us to execute, please call or text our office to see if additional fees apply.

ïƒ˜ Agreement â€“ by scheduling any service with 412 Clean Teams in response to this or any written Proposal made by our company, you acknowledge that you have read this Proposal and agree to all of the applicable Considerations, and that you have independently evaluated the desirability of the service and are not relying on any representation agreement, guarantee or statement other than as set forth in this Proposal. 

ïƒ˜ Feedback - 412 Clean Teams wants to provide the best cleaning services possible.  Please let your Cleaning Technician know if you think they are doing a good job, and/or call us if there is something that can be done better.  We appreciate you and want to be sure you're happy with our work!

text: Hi beautiful friends! Can anyone share their price lists for commercial businesses? How do you all work that out? Iâ€™m from Quebec, Canada ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¦ ðŸ˜˜

topComments.text:
I'm commercial only though I'm not from Canada (though I've run through Ottawa w/ a portion into Quebec...fun place). 

I don't do price lists. If I bid on five locations at 10,000 sqft each all five prices will be different despite the exact same size. Each location has a different scope of work. Each may have different frequencies. Some clients are more pickier than others and that impacts my pricing. It may take 4 hours to clean a 10K sqft office suite but less than an hour to clean a 10,000 sqft warehouse. 10K sqft in cubicle space can take as much as 2X the time when compared to cleaning 10K sqft of enclosed offices and open floor plans. Because of these things and more, we don't standardize our pricing. We might charge $30/hr in one location but $100/hour in another for basic office cleaning.

text:
How do your teach someone to dust?  
How do your teach someone to dust?  

We have a written dusting procedure.  

We have a checklist that specifies ceiling fans, light fixtures, blinds, wall hangings, decor, lamps, windowsils and ledges, furniture, baseboards, door and window frames, upper and lower corners. 

They are taught to "dust everything every time" even if it doesn't "look dusty"

I have a tech still missing things.  A significant amount of things.  Even when she knows I'm coming to check her work.   She always says she "thought she did a good job" and I believe her.   

Once, I asked her to go re- dust a lamp bc it had visible dust left after she dusted.   I watched her walk over there, and dust it again.   Then I went to recheck the lamp and it WAS STILL DUSTY. She had dusted it but missed some of the major dusty areas.   Twice.

So we talked about LOOKING at items to make sure they are clean.   

We've retrained her on dusting.  

She's had written warnings and eventually if this doesn't improve we won't be able to keep her on.

Am I missing anything?

topComments.text: Maybe tell her to dry dust and wet dust to insure she gets all dust that may settle.
I was going to say the same thing as others have said some people are just not cleaners

text:
**[PF Cleaning Adelaide - 5 months review]**

Hey everyone! I thought itâ€™d be interesting to share a bit about my journey as a small business owner.

I run PF Cleaning Adelaide, with my wife helping me manage things. For a while, it was just a glorified sole-trader business, but five months ago, I decided to go all in, hiring, training, advertising, and actually scaling it into a real business.

***Background Context***
Iâ€™ve always wanted to own a local business, but I wasnâ€™t sure what to start.

Iâ€™ve worked as a marketing coordinator for nearly 7 years, so generating leads was easy. The challenge? Finding something I could learn from scratch, train others in, and eventually build into a business.

Iâ€™m not a plumber, electrician, carpenter, detailer, or dog groomer, so those were out. But back when I lived in Brazil, I made a decision: when I moved to Australia, I would work as a cleaner.

And thatâ€™s exactly what I did. Once I arrived, I landed a cleaning job andâ€¦ turns out, I LOVE CLEANING!

I donâ€™t know whatâ€™s wrong with me ahaha I genuinely enjoy it!

Anyway, I thought hiring people would be easy. I was so wrong.

Australia is facing a massive labor shortage, with fewer immigrants and students coming in. On top of that, most people donâ€™t actually like cleaning, itâ€™s just a job they accept because they need to pay the bills.

My biggest pain point has been finding decent teams to allow growth.

Please consider I will use Australian Dolars instead of USD. ðŸ˜Š

***A quick snapshot of my current status***
25 jobs per week, approx $3913 per week, 7 cleaning teams, 37 new leads per week, 13 reviews on google, 4.8 stars average

***Investments***
Currently spending $150 per week on ADS, $120-$200 per week on a part time assistant, $90 per month on software, insurance, hosting etc.. Nothing fancy.

I still can't make a living of the cleaning business, so I still work as a part-time marketing coordinator.

***Goals***
My current goals are to reach 40 jobs per week.

Itâ€™s been a wild five months, I have almost quit two times, and Iâ€™m excited to see where this goes. Thanks for reading!

if youâ€™ve got any questions (or hiring tips ðŸ˜‚), drop them in the comments!

topComments.text:

Amazing story! Youâ€™ve accomplished so much in 5 months ðŸ‘ðŸ¾ðŸ‘ðŸ¾ðŸ‘ðŸ¾. Iâ€™m interested to know what you did for lead generation. Iâ€™m just a month in and looking for pointers! Thanks a lot

text: How many locations do you have?

After 2 years in business, I am finally raising my pricesðŸ™Œ I have 2 questionsâ€¦.

1. Do you have clients sign something or just email a notice?
2. Do you do percentage increase for all clients or flat amount depending on what they are currently paying (i.e. $150 to $160)

topComments.text: Great job on raising your prices! It's not an easy thing to do. We also raise our prices, but we prepare our clients by having them sign guidelines and agreements beforehand.

Good for you finally raising your price! I recommend checking the current rates for cleaning services in your area to see what your competitors are charging. This will give you a better idea of the fair market value and help you adjust your prices accordingly.

It's also important to factor in paying your cleaning techs a good living wage. Pricing your services correctly not only ensures your business remains profitable but also helps you attract and retain quality employees.

When we adjust our prices, we always send an email to our clients informing them of the change. Typically, we provide at least 2 weeks notice before the new rate takes effect.

topComments.text:
We LOVE this stuff. Clients always comment it smells like a hospital so clean and disinfected. However you do have to dilute it much more for glass which we can never get it to be perfect on so we use another cleaner.

text:
How would you sort this problem? IT question! 
We are a residential cleaning company of about 80 cleaners, 5 office staff and 5 VAs. All the office staff and VAs access the same email, and we assign Gmail  emails via labels to our VAs. We delegate our main inbox so the VAs have access to the e-mails, however, this isn't  a perfect solution. 

The main issue lies in VAs not having access to our Google Tasks that our office uses every day to prioritise the most urgent tasks. 

Example:
If 3 clients cancelled with a short notice after hours, we usually attach these emails to Google tasks with a clear instructions on what to do in the morning rush next day, without loosing time to interpret long emails, as time is limited if you need to instruct cleaner to start driving to a different job or swap some jobs. We always attach email there as a reference. 

The problem is, if we use any other software for daily tasks like this, and our VAs will be able to use it, we cannot attach emails. 

How would you sort it? The volume of emails and events daily is huge, so we are looking for the most efficient and safe solution.

topComments.text: Look into Missive. You can delegate emails to certain people, have tasks, have calendars, connect all of your emails and social media to it, even text lines. You can communicate with your team on individual emails or messages without the sender seeing, etc. it has a ton of features that would help with your work flow.

text:
We seem to be dealing with one of these situations almost every week now. A client claims their home is 5/10, but in reality, itâ€™s an 8-10/10â€”pests, biohazards, pet urine/feces, and heavy cluttered surfaces.

**Our intake process is thorough: **my sales manager reviews the home's condition with customer with a series of very pointed questions by phone, makes it crystal clear that we cannot clean under the conditions above, and takes a** 50% non-refundable deposit** to ensure commitment. We explain that if any of the above conditions are present, we cannot perform service and **THEY WILL BE CHARGED IN FULL** to compensate our teams for time, travel, and lost wages. We state this on a recorded call, then reinforce it with three emails and a text confirming our policies before service. Despite all this, people keep lying about their homeâ€™s condition. 

Right now, I have one who has filed a BBB complaint, is disputing the charge on Stripe, and is threatening legal action and media involvement. Another just came in todayâ€”same story. The client claimed it was a 5/10, but the urine and feces smell was so  overwhelming that my team had to leave (photos attached). 

Have you dealt with this kind of issue before? Any advice on how to minimize disputes or handle them more effectively when they arise?

Appreciate any insight you can share!

topComments.text: If you walk into something like that then leave

Here is my advice; we do the same thing as you and every client has to sign our waiver and service agreement to confirm their spot on our schedule. We do not to in person estimate because it is t feasible. 

Once Docusign is completed and sent back to us we charge a 50%deposit. 

If we get to the home and canâ€™t clean to reasons you stated the we charge a a cancellation/lock-out fee. (That fee needs to be stated on your agreement and not just charged the whole remainder unless stated on agreement)

text:
Hello everyone,

Iâ€™m exploring alternatives to maintaining a storage unit for supplies used by our W-2 employees and am considering implementing a reimbursement program. I have a few questions and would appreciate any insights or experiences you might be able to share:

Has anyone transitioned from a storage unit to a reimbursement system for employee supplies? If so, how was the process managed?

What criteria do you use to determine which supplies are eligible for reimbursement? Are there specific categories or limits on amounts?

How do you handle the approval and reimbursement process? Are there specific tools or software that have proven helpful in streamlining this?

How do you ensure compliance and prevent misuse while maintaining efficiency in processing reimbursements?

Are there any challenges you didn't anticipate when shifting to a reimbursement model?

How do you track and record these reimbursements for accounting and tax purposes?

topComments.text: Following :)

I also wanted to share the legal advice I was given from my business lawyer recently regarding this very situation. :) 

This will be lengthy, but worth the read! 

There are a couple of things that you need to be aware of.  OSHA requires employers to pay for a provide personal protection equipment (PPE). Examples of PPE include hard hats, gloves, goggles, safety shoes, safety glasses, welding helmets and goggles, face shields, chemical protective equipment and fall protection equipment.  For your purposes, I could see that gloves may be necessary since your employees are using chemicals.

 

As to employees buying their own supplies or equipment, The US Dept of Labor, Wage and Hour Division, Fact Sheet #16, prohibits employers from requiring employees to pay for tools or supplies that are considered to be for the benefit of the convenience of the employer if by doing so would reduce their wages below required minimum wage or overtime compensation.  Cleaning supplies and equipment would fall into that category.  The example given is that is being paid minimum wage of $7.25, an employer may not take any deduction for the wages for the cost of a uniform nor may the employer require the employee to purchase the uniform on his/her own. However, if the employee were paid $7.75 per hour and worked 30 hours in the workweek, the maximum amount the employer could legally deduct from the employee's wages would be $15.00 ($.50 X 30 hours).  An employer may prorate deductions for the cost of the uniform over a period of paydays provided the prorated deductions do not reduce the employee's wages below the required minimum wage or overtime compensation in any work week.

 

As it applies to supplies, the DOL has stated that the cost of any items which are considered primarily for the benefit or convenience of the employer would have the same restrictions as apply to reimbursement for uniforms. In other words, no deduction may be made from an employee's wages which would reduce the employee's earnings below the required minimum wage or overtime compensation.  Some examples of items considered to be for the benefit or convenience of the employer are tools used in the employee's work, damages to the employer's property by the employee or any other individuals, financial losses due to clients/customers not paying bills, and theft of the employer's property by the employee or other individuals (this is good to know given the employee we believe was taking supplies). Employees may not be required to pay for any of the cost of such items if, by so doing, their wages would be reduced below the required minimum wage or overtime compensation. This is true even if an economic loss suffered by the employer is due to the employee's negligence.  The fact that is says any indicates that it is all or nothing.

 

If an employer requires a minimum-wage employee to provide his own â€œtoolsâ€ for work, the employer must reimburse him for 100% of the cost of doing so.  I know you pay more than minimum wage but am not sure where this leaves you.  If you paid an employee $15 an hour and they work 30 hours a week, they are earning $232.50 more a week than minimum wage would provide which I would think would cover most things. But, if you have an employee that only works 10 hours a week, they earn $77.50 more than minimum wage, which would cause a problem if they need say a vacuum.

topComments.text:
Here you go Larissa Kleemola

What to Include in Customer Guidelines

Welcome/Intro - In this intro paragraph, youâ€™ll simply thank them for choosing your company and welcome them.

How To Prepare for Cleaning - Let your customers know what they can do to prepare for cleaning 

Parking (for city services) - What is the parking situation? Will you be charged for parking, and will you pass that fee along to your client?

Entry Information - Outline your policy on gaining entry to the home. 

Employee Info - Let them know your employees are trained if they are bonded, background checked, etc. State in this section if they can rely on the same cleaner each visit or if having the same cleaner is not a guarantee.

Arrival Info - Outline how your arrivals work. Most owners let their clients know the cleaner(s) will be there within 30 minutes to an hour of the appointment time on their reminder notice.

Things Your Company Does Not Clean - Be specific in listing out things your company does not do during a cleaning. For example, most companies do not clean pet feces, wash walls, hand wipe chandeliers, clean up after excessive bodily fluids (outside what you run across in a normal bathroom cleaning), empty shredder trash without permission, empty diaper pails, etc. This is also a good time to let them know your policy on items being moved for cleaning.

Payment Requirements - Make sure your guidelines state your payment requirements. You need to let the customer know what forms of payment you expect and when payment is expected. If you keep a card on file, make sure to let them know when the card will be run for each appointment.

Tipping - Including a short statement such as â€œTips are not expected but appreciatedâ€ is a good way to let your customers know itâ€™s okay to tip.

Lock Outs and Cancellations Policy - This is an absolute must in this industry. Be very clear on what your fees for lockouts and cancellations are. Include a timeframe for when a cancelation incurs a fee.

Guarantees and/or Refunds - Be sure your clients are aware of any guarantee you offer and if you offer refunds or not. If you do not offer refunds, be sure that is stated in your guidelines.

Price Increases/Adjustments - If you plan on regularly, or as needed, increasing your prices, then make sure your clients know this is a possibility.

Pet Safety - Outline the policy for pets. Most of the time, pets are a wonderful part of the work we do, but if they are skittish or aggressive, make sure your policy makes your client aware it is their responsibility to secure animals.

Valuables - If you work in a lot of high-end homes with a lot of high-end valuables laying about, you may want to write a policy in your guidelines that informs your customer that it is their responsibility to remove anything that cannot be easily replaced or they do not want to be damaged accidentally. Include your policy for making them aware of any damages/breakages during cleaning appointments.

Climate Control - Make sure you have a clear policy on thermostat settings during super hot and super cold months. 

Safety - State any safety policies for the home or crew that the client may need to be made aware of.

Quality - Explain how quality is maintained/managed.

Waivers - Include waivers for things like using their vacuum or any supplies and equipment they provide for the cleaning.
I think we have a list of what to include in the Customer Guidelines in the Rescue Resource Hub. Standby. I'll see if I can hunt it down.

text:
This is probably more of an accounting question but for other business owners. How do you run your payroll cycles?

For example, I run payroll semi monthly. I always thought (for proper accounting) what was worked the 1st-15th gets processed on the 15th, and 16th through last day of the month gets processed last day.

However, pay isnâ€™t deposited into my employees account for 2-3 days after processing. How does someone make payroll post on the day. Are you behind a pay cycle to process it 2-3 days beforehand? 

Hope that makes sense, Iâ€™m trying to find a better system so I can say payday is 15th and last day of the month and employees are paid ON those days.

Thank you!

topComments.text:
I'm on semi monthly. Days worked 1-15 payday is the 20th, days worked 16-last day is paid on the 5th.

Depending on your payroll company, depends on when you process payroll to ensure deposited on time. You'd have to get with payroll company support to find out cut off time.

We do weekly as well using Gusto- we have to process it by 5 pm on Thursday and money hits their accounts on Fridays. Easy peasy. Our staff loves weekly pay. 

As for bookkeeping and budgeting- I just know that the months we have 5 payroll runs we will see a lower profit. I wouldn't get hung up on when the work was completed vs when it gets paid out for. 

 Our pay is calculated off of the previous week, Monday through Sunday.

text: Hey friends.  I'm wondering what everyone is using for route optimization? I'm finally realizing how much money I am wasting on travel.  TIA

topComments.text:
Unfortunately I do it by hand right now. Using Google maps 
If you have a steady handful of recurring clients, it should be easy to navigate once you make what I call a â€œ master scheduleâ€
Which is recurring appointments that donâ€™t ever move and then layer in by ZIP Code going forward.
I hope we can all upvote for an addition in ZenMaid!

Long response: I use Map Developers to define my total service area, then break it into four regions: North, East, South, and West. From there, I identify which clients fall within each section.

To maximize efficiency and minimize travel time, restructure your cleaning schedules so that teams focus on one specific area per day. While this takes some initial effort, it ultimately allows for smoother scheduling and reduced driving time between cleanings.

Once the schedule is set, I use MapQuest or Google Maps to create optimized routes, helping to forecast mileage costs this was the most cost-effective for us.

text:
Google Listing - Adding a second location
A couple of questions! 

We are expanding to a city about 50 miles away. Does it hurt us to list a secondary business address under our current Google listing? 

Also, it looks like it would require its own phone number. Does anyone in here operate with more than one number? 

Thanks in advance for your helpful insight!

topComments.text:
There are a bunch of factors to consider regarding SEO and restructuring your site and GBPs to handle multiple locations, too much to type but I'll cover a couple of matters.

Yes, Google requires each listing to have a separate number.  You can easily add a second line with a VOIP provider and auto forward to the same number if needed.

You also can no longer link the GBPs to your home page.

No two GBPs should ever link to the same URL.

Lots of other stuff involved but again, way too much to type.

You're anonymous so maybe you might not be open to it, but you're welcome to come on to our live podcast to get all your questions answered that should be far more valuable to you than any reason you'd have to remain anonymous.

The impact to your bottom line plus the saving of tons of money by avoiding bad advice that could penalize you should be worth it.

We'd also link to your website from our channel for added promotional value.

Let me know if interested or at least be willing to privately share your concerns as to why you prefer to be anonymous because it's such a great question and the insights can be valuable to business owners all over the world.

text:
Weâ€™re transitioning from contractors to employees and will need to pay for drive time between cleans. I was thinking about creating a separate appointment for each cleaner in ZenMaid to track it. But before I set it up that way, I wanted to see if anyone has a more efficient method.

Would love to hear whatâ€™s working for other companies!

topComments.text:
I developed the P2 Calculator (Profit Predictability) that incorporates GPS tracking, base minimum wage for driving time pay and profit sharing for on-site performance.

It helps me always comply with California labor laws and incentivise productivity, eliminating anyone "milking the clock".

Plus an added benefit: I almost always earn my predesignated profit % as the owner instead of hoping there is something left for me at the end.

It's a win-win-win model without the expense of forming an ESOP nor the worry of any legitimate employee initiated wage theft lawsuits.
